Hozier's soulful, bluesy debut single that tackles themes of religion and sexuality with its powerful chorus.
Dua Lipa's disco-pop smash hit that became one of the longest-charting songs in Billboard history.
The lead single from Dua Lipa's 'Future Nostalgia' album, a dance-pop song about moving on from a relationship.
Avicii's groundbreaking track that mixed folk music with electronic dance music, featuring vocals by Aloe Blacc.
One of the most famous EDM tracks of all time by Avicii, which samples Etta James and became a festival anthem.
David Guetta's house-pop anthem featuring powerful vocals by Sia about being bulletproof and strong.
The Chainsmokers' record-breaking collaboration with Halsey that dominated the charts in 2016.
Adele's 2015 comeback single, famous for its simple piano melody and her powerhouse vocal performance.
The K-pop phenomenon by Psy that became the first video to ever reach one billion views on YouTube.
The first English-language single by BTS, which became their first number-one hit in the United States.
The Black Eyed Peas' ultimate party anthem, famous for its 'Tonight's gonna be a good night' lyrics.
Bruno Mars' debut solo single, a sweet pop ballad that praises a partner's beauty just as it is.
A Police-inspired rock-pop hit by Bruno Mars that showed his versatility as a performer.
Kanye West's Daft Punk-sampling rap hit about how everything that doesn't kill you makes you stronger.
Billy Joel's tribute to 1960s doo-wop music, famous for its catchy melody and music video featuring Christie Brinkley.
Billy Joel's signature song based on his real-life experience playing in a piano bar in Los Angeles.
Elton John's breakthrough hit, a simple and timeless love ballad that is considered one of the greatest songs ever written.
A beloved Elton John classic about life in California, which had a major resurgence after the movie 'Almost Famous.'
The Police's biggest hit, featuring Sting, which is often mistaken for a love song despite its dark lyrics about stalking.
Whitney Houston's upbeat 80s dance-pop classic that remains a favorite at dance parties worldwide.
George Michael's legendary ballad famous for its 'guilty feet have got no rhythm' lyrics and its iconic saxophone intro.
George Michael's solo rock-and-roll hit featuring a famous acoustic guitar rhythm and his signature leather jacket look.
Leonard Cohen's haunting masterpiece, later made famous by Jeff Buckley and featured in the movie 'Shrek.'
A bass-heavy hit by Queen that was inspired by disco and became a massive cross-genre success.
Queen's stadium anthem featuring a 'stomp-stomp-clap' beat that is played at sporting events around the globe.
Queen's classic victory anthem, usually played after a sports team wins a major trophy or tournament.
The Red Hot Chili Peppers' melodic ballad about loneliness and the city of Los Angeles.
A hit by the Red Hot Chili Peppers that critiques the dark side of Hollywood and global culture.
Linkin Park's defining nu-metal track, famous for the interplay between Chester Bennington's singing and Mike Shinoda's rapping.
A powerful Linkin Park anthem about the pressure to live up to others' expectations.
The Eurythmics' synth-pop masterpiece featuring Annie Lennox's distinctive look and voice.

word: Girls Just Want to Have Fun
explanation: Cyndi Lauper's vibrant 80s anthem that celebrated female friendship and independence.
Bonnie Tyler's epic power ballad known for its dramatic production and intense vocal performance.
A smooth-voiced jazz pianist and singer famous for classics like 'Unforgettable' and 'The Christmas Song.'
The 'Godfather of Soul,' known for his incredible showmanship and hits like 'I Got You (I Feel Good).'
The 'Prince of Motown' whose smooth voice defined soul music with hits like 'What's Going On' and 'Sexual Healing.'
The family group that introduced Michael Jackson to the world, famous for 'I Want You Back' and 'ABC.'
An icon of outlaw country music known for his unique singing voice and for hits like 'On the Road Again.'
A British rock and pop singer with a distinctive raspy voice, famous for 'Maggie May' and 'Da Ya Think I'm Sexy?'
The 'Quiet Beatle' who introduced Indian spirituality and the sitar to popular music, famous for 'My Sweet Lord.'
The drummer for The Beatles who also sang hits like 'Yellow Submarine' and 'With a Little Help from My Friends.'
A legendary blues and rock guitarist and singer famous for 'Layla,' 'Wonderful Tonight,' and 'Tears in Heaven.'
A pioneering guitarist who blended rock and Latin music, famous for hits like 'Black Magic Woman' and 'Smooth.'
The country-rock band whose 'Greatest Hits' album is one of the best-selling of all time, famous for 'Hotel California.'
One of the most successful and long-lasting grunge bands, led by the distinctive voice of Eddie Vedder.
The pioneering alternative rock band from Georgia famous for hits like 'Losing My Religion' and 'Everybody Hurts.'
The influential 80s indie band led by Morrissey and guitarist Johnny Marr.
The Britpop band famous for 'Song 2' and their rivalry with Oasis in the mid-1990s.
The Puerto Rican singer who sparked the 'Latin Pop explosion' in the late 90s with the hit 'Livin' la Vida Loca.'
The 'King of Latin Pop' famous for romantic ballads and dance hits like 'Hero' and 'Bailando.'
The Norwegian band famous for the 80s classic 'Take On Me' and its innovative sketch-animation music video.
One of the most famous 80s synth-pop songs ever, known for its high-pitched vocals and animated video.
A classic disco song by The Village People, famous for the arm movements that spell out the letters in the title.
A popular Italian dish consisting of a flat, round base of dough baked with tomato sauce, cheese, and various toppings. It is one of the most widely consumed foods in the world.
A sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun. It is often served with cheese, lettuce, and tomato.

A traditional Japanese dish of prepared vinegared rice, usually with some sugar and salt, accompanied by a variety of ingredients such as seafood and vegetables. It is often served with wasabi and soy sauce.
A traditional Mexican dish consisting of a small hand-sized corn or wheat tortilla topped with a filling. The tortilla is then folded around the filling and eaten by hand.
A staple food of Italian cuisine made from an unleavened dough of wheat flour mixed with water or eggs. It comes in many shapes like spaghetti, penne, and fusilli.
A sweetened frozen food typically eaten as a snack or dessert, made from dairy milk or cream. It is flavored with a sweetener and spices like cocoa or vanilla.
A brewed drink prepared from roasted coffee beans, the seeds of berries from certain flowering plants in the Coffea genus. It is one of the most popular caffeinated beverages globally.

An aromatic beverage prepared by pouring hot or boiling water over cured or fresh leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant. It can be served hot or cold and is the most widely consumed drink in the world after water.
A food made from roasted and ground cacao seeds, typically produced in the form of a liquid, paste, or in a block. It is a key ingredient in many desserts and candies.
Batonnet or allumette-cut deep-fried potatoes that are popular as a side dish or snack. They are commonly served with ketchup or mayonnaise.
A food consisting of a grilled or steamed sausage served in the slit of a partially sliced bun. It is a classic American street food often topped with mustard or sauerkraut.
A flat cake, often thin and round, prepared from a starch-based batter that may contain eggs, milk, and butter. It is typically cooked on a hot surface and served for breakfast.
A type of leavened fried dough which is often ring-shaped and covered in sugar, glaze, or frosting. They can also be filled with jam or cream.
A food item consisting of vegetables, sliced cheese or meat, placed on or between slices of bread. It is a common portable lunch food.
A dish consisting of pieces of food in a mixture, with at least one raw ingredient, usually greens. It is often served with a dressing made of oil and vinegar or cream.
A primarily liquid food, generally served warm or hot, that is made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock or water. Examples include tomato, chicken noodle, and onion.
A high-quality meat slice that is usually grilled, pan-fried, or broiled. It is most commonly associated with beef, but can also refer to fish or other meats.
A type of salt-cured pork made from various cuts, typically from the pork belly or from the back cuts. It is often fried until crispy and served for breakfast.
A dairy product derived from milk that is produced in a wide range of flavors, textures, and forms. Popular varieties include Cheddar, Mozzarella, and Brie.
A staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually by baking. It has been a major part of the human diet since prehistoric times.
A nutrient-rich liquid food produced by the mammary glands of mammals. It is most commonly consumed by humans from cows, goats, and sheep.
A liquid extract of the orange tree fruit, produced by squeezing or macerating oranges. It is a very common breakfast beverage.
A long, curved fruit with a yellow skin and soft, sweet flesh. It grows in clusters on large herbaceous plants and is a major source of potassium.
A widely grown hybrid species of the genus Fragaria, known for its characteristic aroma, bright red color, and juicy texture. It is actually a member of the rose family.
A large, heavy fruit with a green rind and a sweet, juicy red or pink interior. It is composed of about 92% water and is popular in the summer.
A tropical plant with an edible fruit consisting of coalesced berries. It is known for its spiky skin and sweet, acidic yellow flesh.
A starchy tuberous crop from the perennial nightshade Solanum tuberosum. It is one of the most versatile vegetables, used for boiling, baking, and frying.
The edible, often red, berry of the plant Solanum lycopersicum. While botanically a fruit, it is treated as a vegetable in cooking and is the base for many sauces.
An organic vessel laid by female animals, most commonly chickens, which is a versatile protein source in cooking. They can be boiled, fried, scrambled, or poached.
A dairy product made from the fat and protein components of churned cream. It is used as a spread and as a fat for cooking and baking.
A food produced by bacterial fermentation of milk, resulting in a thick, creamy consistency and a tangy flavor. It is often mixed with fruit or honey.
A sweet, viscous food substance made by honey bees and some related insects. Bees produce it from the sugary secretions of plants through regurgitation.
The seed of the grass species Oryza sativa, which is a staple food for a large part of the world's human population. It is grown in flooded fields called paddies.
A type of food made from unleavened dough which is rolled flat and cut, stretched or extruded, into long strips or strings. They are a staple in many Asian and European cuisines.
A variety of corn kernel which expands and puffs up when heated. It is a popular snack food, especially in movie theaters, often served with butter and salt.
Thin slices of potato or corn that have been deep-fried or baked until crunchy. They are a common snack food and come in many different flavors.
A type of baked pastry made from dough that is commonly shaped into a knot. They can be hard and crunchy or soft and chewy.
A baked or cooked food that is typically small, flat and sweet. It usually contains flour, sugar, and some type of oil or fat, often with chocolate chips or raisins.
A form of sweet food made from flour, sugar, and other ingredients, that is usually baked. It is often served as a celebratory dish on ceremonial occasions, such as weddings and birthdays.
A baked dish which is usually made of a pastry dough casing that contains a filling of various sweet or savory ingredients. Common varieties include apple, pumpkin, and meat pies.
An alcoholic drink made from fermented grapes or other fruits. It is generally categorized by its color, such as red, white, or rosé.
One of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, brewed from cereal grains—most commonly from malted barley. It is often carbonated and has a bitter taste.
A type of distilled alcoholic beverage made from fermented grain mash. Various grains are used for different varieties, including barley, corn, rye, and wheat.
A clear distilled alcoholic beverage originating from Poland and Russia. It is composed primarily of water and ethanol and is often used as a base for cocktails.
A distilled beverage made from the blue agave plant, primarily in the area surrounding the city of Tequila in Mexico. It is often served with salt and lime.
A distilled alcoholic drink made from sugarcane byproducts, such as molasses or sugarcane juice. It is famously associated with the Caribbean and pirates.
A distilled alcoholic drink that derives its predominant flavor from juniper berries. It is a key ingredient in a classic Martini or a Gin and Tonic.
A sparkling wine originated and produced in the Champagne region of France. It is associated with luxury and celebrations.
A thick, cold beverage made from pureed raw fruit or vegetables, often combined with milk, yogurt, or ice. It is a popular health-conscious drink.
A sweetened lemon-flavored beverage, usually made from lemon juice, water, and sugar. It is a classic refreshment in the summer.
A sweet, cold beverage that is usually made from milk, ice cream, or iced milk, and flavorings or sweeteners such as butterscotch, caramel, or fruit syrup.
A Mexican-American dish consisting of a flour tortilla wrapped into a sealed cylindrical shape around various ingredients. Typical fillings include meat, beans, and rice.
A Mexican regional dish that consists of heated tortilla chips covered with melted cheese, often served as a snack or appetizer. They are frequently topped with jalapeños and salsa.
An avocado-based dip, spread, or salad first developed in Mexico. It is traditionally made by mashing ripe avocados and sea salt with a mortar and pestle.
The Spanish word for sauce, referring to a variety of sauces used as condiments for tacos and other Mexican foods. It is often made with tomatoes, onions, and chili peppers.
A variety of dishes originating in the Indian subcontinent that use a complex combination of spices and herbs, usually including turmeric and cumin. It is often served with rice or bread.
A Japanese noodle soup consisting of Chinese-style wheat noodles served in a meat or fish-based broth. It is often flavored with soy sauce or miso and uses toppings like sliced pork.
A type of wide, flat pasta, and also the name of an Italian dish made with several layers of lasagna sheets with various fillings like meat and cheese.
A long, thin, solid, cylindrical noodle pasta that is a staple food of traditional Italian cuisine. It is most famously served with tomato sauce or meatballs.
A dish of cooked macaroni pasta and a cheese sauce, most commonly cheddar. It is a popular comfort food in many English-speaking countries.
A dish made from beaten eggs fried with butter or oil in a frying pan, often folded around a filling such as cheese, vegetables, or meat.
A dish made from leavened batter or dough that is cooked between two plates that are patterned to give a characteristic size, shape, and surface impression.
An individual-sized, baked product that can refer to two distinct items: a part-raised flatbread or a cupcake-like quickbread. Common varieties include blueberry and chocolate chip.
A bread product originating in the Jewish communities of Poland, traditionally shaped by hand into the form of a ring. It is boiled before being baked, giving it a chewy interior.
A buttery, flaky, viennoiserie pastry of Austrian origin, but named for its historical crescent shape. It is a staple of French bakeries.
A long, thin loaf of French bread that is commonly made from basic lean dough. It is distinguishable by its length and crisp crust.
A food paste or spread made from ground, dry-roasted peanuts. It is often used in sandwiches, particularly with jelly or jam.
A thick spread made from fruit and sugar that has been boiled until it reaches a gel-like consistency. It is commonly eaten on toast or in sandwiches.
A syrup usually made from the xylem sap of sugar maple, red maple, or black maple trees. It is a famous topping for pancakes and waffles.
A sweet and tangy condiment made from tomatoes, sugar, and vinegar, with seasonings and spices. it is the most popular accompaniment for fries and burgers.
A condiment made from the seeds of a mustard plant, which can be yellowish or brown and has a sharp, pungent flavor.
A thick, creamy dressing often used as a condiment, made from egg yolks, oil, and vinegar or lemon juice.
A liquid condiment of Chinese origin, made from a fermented paste of soybeans, roasted grain, brine, and Aspergillus oryzae. It is essential in many East Asian cuisines.
A liquid fat obtained from olives, a traditional tree crop of the Mediterranean Basin. It is used in cooking, cosmetics, and as a salad dressing.
A species of bulbous flowering plant in the genus Allium, closely related to onions and leeks. It is used worldwide for its strong flavor as a seasoning or condiment.
A vegetable that is the most widely cultivated species of the genus Allium. It has a strong, sharp flavor and is a base ingredient in almost every cuisine.
A root vegetable, usually orange in color, though purple, black, red, white, and yellow cultivars exist. It is crunchy when raw and sweet when cooked.
An edible green plant in the cabbage family whose large flowering head, stalk and small associated leaves are eaten as a vegetable. It looks like a small green tree.
A leafy green flowering plant native to central and western Asia. Its leaves are a common edible vegetable, famously eaten by the character Popeye for strength.
A widely-cultivated creeping vine plant that bears cylindrical fruits used as culinary vegetables. They are often eaten raw in salads or pickled in vinegar.
A cucumber that has been pickled in a brine, vinegar, or other solution and left to ferment for a period of time. It is often served as a side or on burgers.
A bright green fruit with a large pit and dark leathery skin. It is known for its high healthy fat content and is the main ingredient in guacamole.
An edible stone fruit produced by the tropical tree Mangifera indica. It is known for its sweet, juicy orange flesh and is called the 'king of fruits' in some cultures.
A fruit, botanically a berry, of the deciduous woody vines of the flowering plant genus Vitis. They are used for making wine, jam, and raisins.
A citrus fruit known for its bright color and high Vitamin C content. It has a thick skin and is divided into juicy segments inside.
A yellow, oval-shaped citrus fruit with a very sour taste. Its juice and zest are used for flavoring food and drinks like lemonade.
A round, juicy fruit with a fuzzy skin and a large stone in the center. It is sweet and often associated with the state of Georgia.
A sweet, juicy fruit that is typically narrow at the stem and wider at the base. It can be eaten raw or used in desserts.
A small, round, dark blue fruit that grows on bushes. They are sweet and are often used in muffins, pancakes, and smoothies.
A carbonated beverage that is typically sweetened and flavored. Popular examples include cola, lemon-lime, and root beer.
A type of beverage containing stimulant compounds, usually caffeine, which is marketed as providing mental and physical stimulation. Brands include Red Bull and Monster.
A form of cold tea, often served in a glass with ice. It may be sweetened with sugar or syrup and is a popular summer drink.
A heated beverage consisting of shaved chocolate, melted chocolate or cocoa powder, heated milk or water, and usually a sweetener. It is often topped with marshmallows.
A concentrated form of coffee served in small, strong shots and is the base for many other coffee drinks as well as being a drink itself.
An espresso-based coffee drink that originated in Italy and is prepared with steamed milk foam. It is often topped with a sprinkle of cinnamon or cocoa.
A coffee drink made with espresso and a large amount of steamed milk. It is smoother and milkier than a cappuccino.
A classic cocktail consisting of tequila, orange liqueur, and lime juice often served with salt on the rim of the glass. It is a popular drink in Mexican restaurants.
A cocktail made with gin and vermouth, and garnished with an olive or a lemon twist. It is often associated with sophistication and James Bond.
A traditional Cuban highball cocktail consisting of white rum, sugar, lime juice, soda water, and mint. It is known for its refreshing and citrusy taste.
A sweetened dairy-based beverage made with milk, cream, sugar, whipped egg whites, and egg yolks. It is traditionally consumed throughout the Christmas season.
The culinary name for meat from cattle, particularly skeletal muscle. It is a major source of protein and is used in burgers, steaks, and roasts.
The culinary name for the domestic pig. It is the most commonly consumed meat worldwide and is used for bacon, ham, and pork chops.
A popular type of fish known for its pinkish-orange flesh and high omega-3 fatty acid content. It is often eaten grilled, smoked, or raw in sushi.
A large saltwater fish that is a major part of the commercial fishing industry. It is commonly eaten canned or as fresh steaks and sushi.
Small, swimming crustaceans with long bodies that are a very popular type of seafood. They are often served boiled, fried, or in a cocktail.
A thin slice of potato that has been deep fried or baked until crunchy, and then salted. They are one of the most popular snack foods in the world.
Deep-fried, grated potatoes served as a side dish, recognizable by their compact cylindrical shape and crispy exterior.
A dish made by boiling potatoes and then crushing them until they are smooth, often with the addition of milk and butter.
A culinary term for a cooked ear of freshly picked maize from a cultivar of sweet corn, usually eaten with butter and salt.
A quick bread made with cornmeal and associated with the cuisine of the Southern United States.
A food prepared by coagulating soy milk and then pressing the resulting curds into solid white blocks. It is a popular meat substitute in vegetarian and vegan diets.
A Middle Eastern dip or spread made from cooked, mashed chickpeas blended with tahini, lemon juice, and garlic. It is often served with pita bread.
A yeast-leavened round flatbread baked from wheat flour, common in the Mediterranean and Middle East. It often has a pocket inside that can be filled with food.
A deep-fried ball or patty made from ground chickpeas, fava beans, or both. It is a popular Middle Eastern street food often served in a pita.
A layered pastry dessert made of filo dough, filled with chopped nuts, and sweetened with syrup or honey. It is a popular sweet in many Middle Eastern and Mediterranean countries.
A dish of pieces of meat, fish, or vegetables roasted or grilled on a skewer or spit. It originated in the Middle East and is now popular worldwide.
A Spanish rice dish originally from Valencia, known for its use of saffron which gives the rice a bright yellow color. It usually contains seafood or meat.
A northern Italian rice dish cooked with broth until it reaches a creamy consistency. It is often flavored with parmesan cheese, onions, and butter.
An Italian appetizer consisting of grilled bread rubbed with garlic and topped with olive oil and salt. The most popular variation is topped with chopped tomatoes and basil.
A variety of pasta consisting of small, thick, soft dough dumplings. They are most commonly made from semolina, ordinary wheat flour, or potato.
The Italian word for ice cream, though it is usually denser and has less fat than American-style ice cream. It is served at a slightly warmer temperature.
A coffee-flavored Italian dessert made of ladyfingers dipped in coffee, layered with a whipped mixture of eggs, sugar, and mascarpone cheese.
Italian pastries consisting of tube-shaped shells of fried pastry dough, filled with a sweet, creamy filling usually containing ricotta.
A Mexican dish consisting of a tortilla that is filled primarily with cheese, and sometimes meats and spices, and then cooked on a griddle.
A corn tortilla rolled around a filling and covered with a savory sauce, typically including chili pepper. It is a staple of Mexican cuisine.
A fried-dough pastry—predominantly choux—based snack, often coated in cinnamon and sugar. They are popular in Spain, Portugal, and Latin America.
A Latin American seafood dish made from fresh raw fish cured in fresh citrus juices, most commonly lemon or lime. It is often spiced with ají or chili peppers.
A large range of small Chinese dishes that are traditionally enjoyed in restaurants for brunch. It includes a variety of dumplings, buns, and other snacks.
A dish of cooked rice that has been stir-fried in a wok or a frying pan and is usually mixed with other ingredients such as eggs, vegetables, and meat.
A large variety of filled, rolled appetizers or dim sum found in East Asian, South Asian, and Southeast Asian cuisine. They are often deep-fried until crispy.
A spicy, stir-fried Chinese dish made with cubes of chicken, peanuts, vegetables, and chili peppers. It is a staple of Szechuan cuisine.
A crisp and sugary cookie wafer made from flour, sugar, vanilla, and sesame seed oil with a piece of paper inside with a 'fortune' written on it.
A traditional Japanese soup consisting of a dashi stock into which softened miso paste is mixed. It often contains tofu and seaweed.
A typical Japanese dish usually consisting of seafood, meat and vegetables that have been battered and deep fried.
A stir-fried rice noodle dish commonly served as a street food and at most restaurants in Thailand. It is known for its balance of sweet, sour, and salty flavors.
A Vietnamese soup dish consisting of broth, rice noodles, herbs, and meat, usually beef or chicken. It is a popular street food in Vietnam.
A dish of French fries and cheese curds topped with a brown gravy. It emerged in the late 1950s in the Canadian province of Quebec.
A sour soup common in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia, of which the main ingredient is beetroot. It gives the soup a distinctive deep red color.
A soup or stew of meat and vegetables seasoned with paprika and other spices. It originated in medieval Hungary and is a national symbol of the country.
A ground meat pie with a crust or topping of mashed potato. Technically, it should be made with lamb, while the beef version is a cottage pie.
A popular hot dish consisting of fried fish in batter served with deep-fried potatoes. It is a classic takeaway food in the United Kingdom.
A French dish consisting of cooked edible land snails. They are often served as an appetizer and cooked with garlic butter and parsley.
A specialty food product made of the liver of a duck or goose. It is a well-known and controversial delicacy in French cuisine.
A savory, open-faced pastry crust with a filling of savory custard with cheese, meat, seafood, or vegetables. The most famous version is Quiche Lorraine.
A baked egg-based dish originating in early 18th-century France. It is made with egg yolks and beaten egg whites, known for its light and airy texture.
A North African dish of small steamed granules of rolled durum wheat semolina. It is traditionally served with a stew spooned on top.
A staple in Korean cuisine, it is a traditional side dish of salted and fermented vegetables, most commonly napa cabbage and Korean radishes.
A Korean rice dish served in a bowl topped with sautéed vegetables, chili pepper paste, and often a raw or fried egg. The name means 'mixed rice.'
A leavened, oven-baked flatbread native to the Indian subcontinent and Central Asia. It is often brushed with ghee or butter.
A fried or baked pastry with a savory filling, such as spiced potatoes, onions, or peas. It is a popular snack in South Asia, the Middle East, and East Africa.
A curry made from chicken with a spiced tomato and butter sauce. It is known for its rich, creamy texture and mild spice level.
A chicken dish prepared by roasting chicken marinated in yogurt and spices in a tandoor, a cylindrical clay oven. It is bright red in color.
A dish consisting of roasted marinated chicken chunks in a spiced sauce. The sauce is usually creamy and orange-colored due to the use of tomato and spices.
A dish from Beijing that has been prepared since the imperial era. It is characterized by its thin, crisp skin and is traditionally served with pancakes and hoisin sauce.
A type of Chinese dumpling commonly found across regional styles of Chinese cuisine. They are often served in a clear broth or deep-fried.
Lean meat that has been trimmed of fat, cut into strips, and then dried to prevent spoilage. It is a popular high-protein snack.
A slow-cooked dish made by simmering beef with vegetables like carrots and potatoes in a thick, savory liquid. It is a common comfort food in cold weather.
A spicy stew containing chili peppers, meat (usually beef), and often tomatoes and beans. It is the official dish of the state of Texas.
Ground meat rolled into a small ball, sometimes along with other ingredients, such as bread crumbs, minced onion, and spices. They are a classic pairing for spaghetti.
A type of meat product usually made from ground meat with salt, spices and other flavorings, wrapped in a casing. They can be grilled, fried, or boiled.
A type of cured sausage consisting of fermented and air-dried meat, typically pork. It is a popular deli meat and pizza topping.
An American variety of salami made from cured pork and beef seasoned with paprika or other chili pepper. It is the most popular pizza topping in the United States.
Pork from a leg cut that has been preserved by wet or dry curing, with or without smoking. It is often served at holidays or sliced in sandwiches.
The culinary name for the meat of a deer. It is a game meat that is leaner than beef and has a slightly stronger flavor.
A small cut of meat from a sheep, usually including a rib bone. They are often grilled or pan-seared and served with mint sauce.
A type of bivalve mollusk that can be eaten raw or cooked. They are often considered an aphrodisiac and a luxury seafood item.
A common name for several kinds of bivalve mollusks. They are often used in chowders, pasta dishes, or steamed in garlic and wine.
A type of edible mollusk with a long, dark blue or black shell. They are commonly steamed with white wine and garlic and served with bread.
A type of marine bivalve mollusk with a fan-shaped shell. The white adductor muscle is prized for its sweet taste and tender texture when seared.
A food consisting of salt-cured roe (eggs) from certain types of fish, most traditionally sturgeon. it is a world-famous luxury delicacy.
Small, oily forage fish in the herring family. They are nutrient-dense and are most commonly sold canned in oil, water, or tomato sauce.
Small, common salt-water forage fish. They are often salt-cured and have a very strong, salty flavor, making them a polarizing pizza topping.
A blend of typically three main ingredients: tuna, eggs, and mayonnaise. It is a common filling for sandwiches and wraps.
A side dish consisting primarily of finely shredded raw cabbage with a salad dressing, commonly either vinaigrette or mayonnaise.
A green salad of romaine lettuce and croutons dressed with lemon juice, olive oil, egg, Worcestershire sauce, anchovies, and parmesan cheese.
A salad in Greek cuisine typically made with pieces of tomatoes, cucumbers, onion, feta cheese, and olives and dressed with olive oil.
A simple Italian salad made of sliced fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, and sweet basil, seasoned with salt and olive oil.
A main-dish American garden salad typically made with chopped salad greens, tomato, crisp bacon, boiled chicken, hard-boiled eggs, avocado, and blue cheese.
A fruit and nut salad generally made of fresh apples, celery, walnuts, and grapes, dressed in mayonnaise.
A soup containing clams and broth, often thickened with crackers or a roux. The two most famous versions are New England (creamy) and Manhattan (tomato-based).
A soup with tomatoes as the primary ingredient. It is a popular comfort food, especially when served with a grilled cheese sandwich.
A type of soup usually based on meat stock and onions, and often served gratiné with croutons and cheese on top.
A thick soup of Italian origin made with vegetables, often with the addition of pasta or rice, sometimes both.
A cold soup made of raw, blended vegetables and originated in the southern regions of the Iberian Peninsula.
A soup with lentils as its main ingredient; it may be vegetarian or include meat, and it is a staple in many cultures.
A stew popular in the U.S. state of Louisiana, consisting of a strongly-flavored stock, meat or shellfish, and a thickener.
The fruiting body of a subterranean fungus, which is highly prized as a food for its intense aroma and flavor. They are one of the most expensive foods in the world.
A spring vegetable, a flowering perennial plant species whose young shoots are used as a culinary vegetable. They are often grilled or steamed.
A variety of a species of thistle cultivated as a food. The edible portion consists of the flower buds before the flowers come into bloom.
A member of the Gemmifera Group of cabbages, grown for its edible buds that look like tiny cabbages.
A delicate, tropical perennial plant often grown as a tender or half-hardy annual in temperate climates. It is known for its deep purple skin and spongy flesh.
A summer squash that can reach nearly a meter in length, but is usually harvested when still immature. It is often used in stir-fries and breads.
A large, orange winter squash that is a symbol of autumn and Halloween. It is used to make pies, soups, and Jack-o'-lanterns.
A large, starchy, sweet-tasting, tuberous root vegetable. It has orange flesh and is often served mashed or as fries.
A cereal grain first domesticated by indigenous peoples in southern Mexico about 10,000 years ago. It is eaten as a vegetable, made into flour, or popped as a snack.
Small, round green seeds that grow in pods on a climbing plant. They are a common side dish and are often sold frozen or canned.
A square or rectangular chocolate baked confection. It is somewhere between a cake and a soft cookie in texture and often contains nuts or chocolate chips.
A sweet dessert consisting of one or more layers, with the main layer being a mixture of soft cheese, sugar, and eggs on a crust made from crushed cookies or graham crackers.
A small cake designed to serve one person, typically baked in a small thin paper or aluminum cup. They are usually topped with frosting and decorations.
A sweet meringue-based confection made with egg white, icing sugar, granulated sugar, and almond meal. It is known for its bright colors and smooth, round top.
A classic fruit pie in which the principal filling ingredient is apples, often served with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
A frozen dessert made from sweetened water with flavoring, usually fruit juice or fruit purée. It is distinct from ice cream because it contains no dairy.
A dessert that typically consists of one or more scoops of ice cream topped with sauce or syrup and other toppings like sprinkles, whipped cream, or a cherry.
A dish where pieces of fruit or marshmallows are dipped into a shared pot of melted chocolate.
A light and airy dessert made by folding whipped cream or beaten egg whites into a flavored chocolate base.
A very thin pancake of French origin, which can be served with sweet fillings like chocolate or savory fillings like ham and cheese.
A dish made of sliced bread soaked in beaten eggs and often milk, then pan-fried. It is usually served with syrup and powdered sugar for breakfast.
A variety of culinary preparations based on a cooked mixture of milk or cream and egg yolk. It can vary in consistency from a thin pouring sauce to a thick cream used for fillings.
A sweet, creamy dessert similar to custard, often flavored with vanilla, chocolate, or butterscotch.
A semi-solid, wobbly dessert made from fruit juice and gelatin. It is often served to children as a snack.
A sugary confection that is soft, puffy, and elastic in consistency. They are commonly roasted over a campfire to make s'mores.
A spun sugar confection that resembles cotton, often sold at carnivals and fairs. It dissolves almost instantly in the mouth.
A type of sugar candy consisting of a hard sweet attached to a stick, intended for sucking or licking.
A confection flavored with the extract of the root of the Glycyrrhiza glabra plant, often sold in black or red rope-like shapes.
Small, fruit-flavored gum candies similar to jelly beans, shaped in the form of a small bear.
A soft, cohesive substance designed to be chewed without being swallowed, often used to freshen breath.
A hybrid mint that is a cross between watermint and spearmint, widely used to flavor candies, gum, and tea.
A medium to dark-orange confectionery product made by heating a variety of sugars. It is used as a flavoring in puddings and desserts or as a filling for chocolates.
A confection made by caramelizing sugar or molasses along with butter, and sometimes flour. It is boiled until it becomes hard and crunchy.
A type of sugar candy that is made by mixing sugar, butter and milk, heating it to a specific consistency, and then beating the mixture while it cools so that it acquires a smooth, creamy texture.
A confection containing nuts—usually pecans or almonds—and sugar, often with cream or butter.
A small unsweetened or lightly sweetened biscuit-like cake made from flour, fat, and milk. It is a traditional part of a British cream tea.
A multilayered, laminated sweet pastry made of yeast-leavened dough, often topped with fruit or cheese.
An oblong pastry made with choux dough filled with a cream and topped with chocolate icing.
A small, hollow pastry made from choux dough, typically filled with cream or ice cream and often drizzled with chocolate sauce.
Italian almond biscuits that are twice-baked, oblong-shaped, dry, and crunchy. They are intended to be dipped in a drink, traditionally coffee.
A preparation of oats that have been de-husked, steamed, and flattened, or a porridge made from these oats.
A cold breakfast dish based on rolled oats and ingredients like grains, nuts, seeds and fresh or dried fruits.
A breakfast food and snack food consisting of rolled oats, nuts, and honey, which is baked until it is crisp.
A breakfast cereal made by toasting flakes of corn, originally created by John Harvey Kellogg.
A dish made by heating or boiling ground, crushed or chopped starchy plants, typically grain, in milk or water. It is a common hot breakfast.
A dish made from eggs stirred, whipped or beaten together while being gently heated, typically with salt and butter.
A dish consisting of chicken pieces that have been coated with seasoned flour or batter and pan-fried, deep fried, or pressure fried.
Unbreaded chicken wings that are generally deep-fried then coated in a vinegar-based cayenne pepper hot sauce and melted butter.
Pork or beef ribs that are slow-cooked on a grill or in a smoker and slathered in a tangy barbecue sauce.
A dish of ground meat that has been combined with other ingredients and formed into the shape of a loaf, then baked or smoked.
A dish of beef which is roasted in an oven and served as a main meal. Leftovers are often used in sandwiches.
An American barbecue dish based on shredded barbecued pork shoulder, typically slow-smoked over wood.
A dish consisting of breaded chicken breast covered with tomato sauce and mozzarella, parmesan, or provolone cheese.
A preparation of fillet steak coated with pâté and mushroom duxelles, which is then wrapped in puff pastry and baked.
A Mexican dish consisting of grilled or fried fish served in a tortilla with cabbage, pico de gallo, and a creamy sauce.
The culinary name for squid, which is often battered and deep-fried as an appetizer and served with lemon and sauce.
A variety of fishcake which is popular in the United States, composed of crab meat and various other ingredients, such as bread crumbs and mayonnaise.
A sandwich native to New England made of lobster meat served on a grilled hot dog-style bun.
A popular dish of West African, French, and Spanish influence, consisting mainly of meat and vegetables mixed with rice, originating in Louisiana.
A dish found in Cajun and Creole cuisine of Louisiana, typically made with shellfish over rice, using a technique known as smothering.
A thick cream-based soup or chowder that is similar to clam chowder, with corn substituted for clams.
A Chinese soup of wispy beaten eggs in boiled chicken broth, often flavored with black or white pepper and finely chopped scallions.
A thick soup made from dried peas, such as the split pea. It is often cooked with ham or bacon for added flavor.
A popular Chinese soup made with ingredients such as bamboo shoots, wood ear edible fungus, and tofu in a broth seasoned with vinegar and pepper.
A side dish found in the Southern United States, made from unripe tomatoes coated with cornmeal and fried.
A form of snack or side dish consisting of a cross-sectional ring of onion dipped in batter or breadcrumbs and then deep-fried.
Elongated pieces of battered or breaded mozzarella cheese, usually served as an appetizer with marinara sauce.
A spicy sauce made from a combination of cayenne pepper, vinegar, and butter, most famously used on chicken wings.
A sauce used as a marinade, basting, topping, or condiment for meat cooked in the barbecue cooking style.
A condiment made of mayonnaise, chopped pickles, capers and herbs, typically served with seafood dishes like fish and chips.
A bright green sauce originating in Genoa, Italy, traditionally consisting of crushed garlic, pine nuts, coarse salt, basil leaves, and hard cheese blended with olive oil.
A dip or sauce found in the cuisines of Southeast Europe and the Middle East, made of salted strained yogurt mixed with cucumbers, garlic, and olive oil.
A fresh tomato-based salsa in Mexican cuisine made from chopped tomato, onion, cilantro, and serrano or jalapeño peppers.
A savory Provençal dish consisting of puréed or finely chopped olives, capers, and anchovies.
A dairy product obtained by fermenting regular cream with certain kinds of lactic acid bacteria, often used as a topping for tacos or baked potatoes.
A soft, mild-tasting fresh cheese with a high fat content, commonly spread on bagels or used as a base for cheesecake.
Heavy cream that has been beaten by a whisk or mixer until it is light and fluffy, often used as a dessert topping.
A fresh cheese curd product with a mild flavor and a lumpy texture, often eaten with fruit or in salads.
A hard, granular Italian cheese that is aged for a long time and is commonly grated over pasta dishes.
A relatively hard, off-white (or orange if colorings are added), sometimes sharp-tasting cheese that originated in the English village of the same name.
A traditionally southern Italian cheese made from Italian buffalo's milk by the pasta filata method. It is famous for its use on pizza.
A generic name in North America for several related varieties of cheese, which resemble Emmental cheese and are famous for having holes.
A general classification of cheeses that have had cultures of the mold Penicillium added so that the final product is spotted or veined throughout with blue or blue-gray mold.
A soft cow's-milk cheese named after Brie, the French region from which it originated. It is pale in color with a slight grayish tinge under a rind of white mold.
A mild, yellow cheese made from cow's milk, originating from the Netherlands. It is one of the most popular cheeses worldwide.
A brined curd white cheese made in Greece from sheep's milk or from a mixture of sheep and goat milk. It is a key ingredient in Greek salads.
A moist, soft, creamy, surface-ripened cow's milk cheese, first made in Normandy, northern France. It is similar to Brie but usually has a stronger flavor.
Immature soybeans in the pod, found in cuisines with origins in East Asia. The pods are boiled or steamed and served with salt.
A plant of the family Brassicaceae, which also includes horseradish and mustard. Its stem is used as a condiment and has an extremely strong pungency more like hot mustard than chili pepper.
A flowering plant whose rhizome is widely used as a spice and a folk medicine. It has a pungent, spicy flavor and is often pickled or used in tea.
A flowering plant of the ginger family, the rhizomes of which are used in cooking. It gives curry its characteristic bright yellow color.
A spice obtained from the inner bark of several tree species from the genus Cinnamomum. It is used in both sweet and savory foods and has a distinct, warm aroma.
A flavoring derived from orchids of the genus Vanilla, primarily obtained from the pods of the Mexican species. It is the most popular flavor for ice cream and baking.
A spice made from the seed of the Myristica fragrans tree. It has a warm, slightly sweet flavor and is often used in holiday baking and eggnog.
A spice derived from the flower of Crocus sativus, known for being the most expensive spice in the world by weight. It adds a distinct yellow-orange color and hay-like flavor to food.
A ground spice made from dried red fruits of the larger and sweeter varieties of the plant Capsicum annuum. It is used to add color and flavor to many types of dishes.
A culinary herb of the family Lamiaceae (mints). It is a key ingredient in Mediterranean and Southeast Asian cuisines, most notably in pesto and Thai dishes.
The leaves of the coriander plant, used as a fresh herb in Mexican and Asian cooking. Some people have a genetic trait that makes it taste like soap.
A highly aromatic herb used for flavoring drinks, desserts, and savory dishes. It is also the primary flavor for toothpaste and gum.
A fragrant evergreen herb with needle-like leaves, often used to season meats like lamb and chicken or roasted potatoes.
A delicate, earthy herb commonly used in stews, soups, and roasted meats. It is a staple of French and Mediterranean cooking.
A woody, aromatic herb that is a staple in Italian and Greek cooking, often used on pizza and in tomato sauces.
A bright green, biennial herb widely used in European, Middle Eastern, and American cuisine. It is often used as a garnish or to add a fresh flavor to dishes.
An annual herb in the celery family, known for its feathery green leaves. It is most commonly associated with flavoring pickles and seafood.
A perennial, evergreen subshrub with woody stems and grayish leaves. It has a strong, earthy flavor often used in stuffing for poultry.
A species of flowering plant in the onion family. Their long, thin green leaves are often chopped and used as a garnish for baked potatoes or omelets.
A tropical grass used as a culinary herb in Southeast Asian cuisine. It has a fresh, lemony scent and is used in soups and curries.
A root vegetable used as a spice and condiment, known for its intense, sinus-clearing heat. It is often served with roast beef or in cocktail sauce.
A chocolate bar featuring nougat and caramel covered in milk chocolate. It was first manufactured in the UK and is the namesake of its parent company.
A chocolate bar made by Mars, Inc., consisting of a biscuit applied with other confectionery toppings and coatings, most frequently caramel and milk chocolate. They usually come in pairs.
A brand of fruit-flavored button-shaped candies with a hard sugar shell. Their famous marketing slogan is 'Taste the Rainbow.'
A crunchy, orange corn puff snack made by Frito-Lay. They are famous for their mascot Chester Cheetah and for leaving orange dust on the fingers.
A milk chocolate egg containing a small plastic capsule with a surprise toy inside. It is a very popular treat for children around the world.
The original gummy bear candy, known for its chewy texture and various fruit flavors. The brand is a global leader in gelatin-based sweets.
The flagship milk chocolate bar of the Hershey Company, considered an American classic. It is a primary ingredient in making s'mores.
A general term for snack bars made primarily of various nuts held together with honey or glucose syrup, often marketed as a healthy energy snack.
A brand of peppermint and fruit-flavored candies sold in mechanical dispensers. The dispensers are often topped with heads of famous pop culture characters.
A brand of prepackaged scotch mints sold in rolls. They became internet-famous for their explosive reaction when dropped into Diet Coke.
Small bean-shaped sugar candies with soft candy shells and thick gel interiors. They come in a vast array of colors and flavors.
A type of candy made by stretching or pulling a sticky mass of boiled sugar, butter, and flavorings until it becomes light and chewy.
Lean meat that has been trimmed of fat, cut into strips, and then dried to prevent spoilage. It is a popular high-protein snack for hikers and travelers.
A brand of rectangular, pre-baked toaster pastries with a sugary filling inside two layers of thin, rectangular crust. They are often frosted on top.
A snack made of oats, nuts, and honey that has been pressed into a bar shape and baked. It is commonly eaten as a quick breakfast or energy boost.
A popular confection made by binding Rice Krispies cereal together with melted butter and marshmallows.
A snack mix consisting of granola, roasted nuts, dried fruit, and sometimes chocolate, designed to be eaten while hiking.
The fruit of the sunflower, often roasted and salted, and eaten as a snack by cracking the shell with one's teeth.
A member of the cashew family, these nuts are known for their green color and for being sold in their partially open shells.
Kidney-shaped seeds that adhere to the bottom of the cashew apple. They are popular as a snack and used in many creamy vegan sauces.
Nuts that grow in a hard shell and are known for their brain-like appearance. They are high in omega-3 fatty acids and common in baking.
A popular tree nut that can be eaten raw, roasted, or used to make milk and flour. They are often found in chocolate bars.
Processed seafood product made using a whitefish which has been battered or breaded. They are a common frozen food for children.
A hot sandwich made with tuna salad and melted cheese, typically served on toasted bread.
A sandwich with three slices of bread and two layers of fillings, typically including turkey, bacon, lettuce, and tomato.
A popular sandwich named after its three main ingredients: bacon, lettuce, and tomato.
A sandwich consisting of ground beef, onions, and tomato sauce or ketchup served on a hamburger bun.
A sandwich made from thinly sliced pieces of beefsteak and melted cheese in a long hoagie roll, originating in Philadelphia.
A sausage on a stick that has been coated in a thick layer of cornmeal batter and deep-fried.
Small pieces of deboned chicken meat that is breaded or battered, then deep-fried or baked. They are a staple of fast-food menus.
A large, doughy baked snack shaped into a knot and sprinkled with coarse salt, often served warm with mustard or cheese dip.
Bread topped with garlic and olive oil or butter, and sometimes herbs like oregano or chives. It is a common side dish for pasta.
A simple Italian pizza topped with tomatoes, sliced mozzarella, fresh basil, and extra-virgin olive oil, representing the colors of the Italian flag.
The most popular pizza variety in the United States, topped with spicy slices of cured pork and beef salami.
A controversial pizza variety topped with tomato sauce, cheese, sliced ham, and pineapple chunks.
A style of pizza developed in Chicago that is baked in a deep pan, resulting in a thick crust and large amounts of sauce and cheese.
An Italian oven-baked folded pizza, often described as a pizza turnover. It is filled with cheeses, meats, and vegetables.
A Chinese dish with wheat flour noodles, often containing vegetables and some type of meat or seafood. The name means 'stirred noodles.'
A sweet and spicy deep-fried chicken dish that is very popular in North American Chinese restaurants.
A classic Chinese dish consisting of deep-fried pork cubes tossed in a vibrant sauce made of sugar, vinegar, and pineapple.
A fried savory roll with shredded cabbage, chopped pork, and other fillings inside a thickly-wrapped wheat flour skin.
A Japanese version of a dumpling, typically filled with ground meat and vegetables and wrapped in a thin dough, then pan-fried.
A Japanese delicacy consisting of very fresh raw fish or meat sliced into thin pieces. Unlike sushi, it is served without rice.
A dish of roasted marinated chicken chunks in a spiced, creamy, orange-colored sauce.
A wide variety of small savory dishes, snacks, or appetizers in Spanish cuisine, often served with drinks in a bar.
A typical Spanish alcoholic beverage consisting of red wine, chopped fruit, and often other ingredients such as orange juice or brandy.
A savory French tart consisting of a pastry crust filled with a custard of eggs and cream, containing bacon and cheese.
A soup based on meat stock and onions, traditionally served with a large piece of bread and melted cheese on top.
A dessert consisting of a rich custard base topped with a layer of hardened caramelized sugar.
A traditional British dish of sausages served with mashed potatoes and often topped with onion gravy.
The national dish of Scotland, a savory pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs) minced with onion and oatmeal.
An Italian pasta dish from Rome made with eggs, hard cheese, cured pork, and black pepper.
A type of pasta comprising a filling enveloped in thin pasta dough, typically served in broth or with a sauce.
A veined Italian blue cheese, made from unskimmed cow's milk. It can be buttery or firm, crumbly and quite salty.
An Italian semi-hard cheese with a mild flavor, often used in sandwiches and melted on dishes.
An Italian whey cheese with a grainy texture and a mild, sweet flavor, commonly used in lasagna and desserts like cannoli.
A very dark, concentrated, and intensely flavored vinegar originating in Italy, made wholly or partially from grape must.
The largest land animal on Earth, known for its long trunk, large ears, and tusks made of ivory.
A tall African mammal with a very long neck and legs, and a distinctive pattern of brown patches on its coat.
A large cat known as the 'King of the Jungle,' where the males are easily recognized by their impressive manes.
The largest species of cat in the world, recognizable by its dark vertical stripes on orange-brown fur.
A flightless bird that lives almost exclusively in the Southern Hemisphere, known for its tuxedo-like appearance and waddling walk.
A large marsupial native to Australia that moves by hopping on its powerful hind legs and carries its young in a pouch.
A highly intelligent marine mammal known for its playful behavior and use of echolocation to navigate and hunt.
A predatory fish with a skeleton made of cartilage, known for its sharp teeth and dorsal fin that often pokes out of the water.
A flying insect known for its role in pollination and for producing honey and beeswax in large colonies called hives.
An insect with large, often brightly colored wings that undergoes a transformation from a caterpillar.
The star at the center of our Solar System that provides the energy and light necessary for life on Earth.
Earth's only natural satellite, which causes the tides in the oceans and goes through different phases each month.
The second-largest planet in our Solar System, famous for its extensive and prominent ring system.
A dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt that was famously considered the ninth planet of our Solar System until 2006.
A region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape from it.
The galaxy that contains our Solar System, appearing as a hazy band of light in the night sky.
A rupture in the crust of a planetary-mass object that allows hot lava, volcanic ash, and gases to escape from a magma chamber below.
The shaking of the surface of the Earth resulting from a sudden release of energy in the Earth's lithosphere that creates seismic waves.
A series of waves in a water body caused by the displacement of a large volume of water, generally in an ocean or a large lake.
A violently rotating column of air that is in contact with both the surface of the Earth and a cumulonimbus cloud.
A rapidly rotating storm system characterized by a low-pressure center, strong winds, and heavy rain, occurring over tropical or subtropical waters.
A naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions in the atmosphere or ground temporarily equalize themselves.
A meteorological phenomenon that is caused by reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets resulting in a spectrum of light appearing in the sky.
The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water.
A molecule that carries the genetic instructions used in the growth, development, functioning, and reproduction of all known living organisms.
A chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, which is essential for the respiration of most living organisms on Earth.
A fundamental interaction which causes mutual attraction between all things that have mass or energy, famously discovered by Isaac Newton.
The smallest unit of ordinary matter that forms a chemical element, consisting of a nucleus of protons and neutrons surrounded by electrons.
The change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations, famously proposed by Charles Darwin.
The long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period due to human activities.
A luxuriant, dense forest rich in biodiversity, found typically in tropical areas with consistently heavy rainfall.
A barren area of landscape where little precipitation occurs and, consequently, living conditions are hostile for plant and animal life.
A persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight, typically found in cold polar or mountainous regions.
An underwater ecosystem characterized by reef-building corals, often called the 'rainforests of the sea' due to their high biodiversity.
A type of biological cell, which are microscopic, single-celled organisms that can be found in every environment on Earth.
A submicroscopic infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of an organism, such as the flu or COVID-19.
A solid form of the element carbon with its atoms arranged in a crystal structure, known as the hardest natural substance on Earth.
A chemical element with the symbol Au and atomic number 79, a highly sought-after precious metal used in jewelry and electronics.
An inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance that is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere.
The solid form of water, typically found in glaciers, polar ice caps, and as frost or snow.
The preserved remains, or traces of remains, of ancient organisms, such as shells, bones, or imprints in stone.
A diverse group of reptiles that were the dominant terrestrial vertebrates for over 160 million years before going extinct.
A marine mammal and the largest animal known to have ever existed, reaching lengths of up to 100 feet.
A large predatory shark found in coastal surface waters of all the major oceans, famous for being the subject of the movie 'Jaws.'
A hypercarnivorous bear whose native range lies largely within the Arctic Circle, known for its white fur and swimming ability.
A bear native to south central China, easily recognized by the large, distinctive black patches around its eyes and ears.
A slow-moving tropical mammal of Central and South America, known for spending most of its life hanging upside down in trees.
A semiaquatic egg-laying mammal endemic to eastern Australia, famous for its duck-like bill and beaver-like tail.
A highly specialized clade of lizards known for their ability to change skin color and their long, sticky tongues.
A soft-bodied, eight-limbed mollusk known for its high intelligence and its ability to squeeze into tiny spaces and change camouflage.
A nocturnal bird of prey known for its large eyes, a flat face, and the ability to turn its head nearly 360 degrees.
A bird of prey found in North America that is the national bird and symbol of the United States.
A very small bird known for its ability to hover in mid-air by rapidly flapping its wings and for drinking nectar from flowers.
A bird known for tapping on tree trunks with its beak to find insects or create holes for nesting.
The largest and heaviest living bird, which is flightless and can run at speeds up to 45 miles per hour.
A tall wading bird known for its pink feathers, long neck, and tendency to stand on one leg.
An elongated, legless, carnivorous reptile of the suborder Serpentes, some of which are venomous.
A large semiaquatic reptile that lives throughout the tropics in Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia, known for its long snout and powerful jaws.
A reptile characterized by a special bony or cartilaginous shell developed from their ribs that acts as a shield.
A tailless amphibian with a short body, webbed digits, and bulging eyes, known for its jumping ability and 'ribbit' sound.
An air-breathing arthropod that has eight legs and fangs that inject venom, often known for spinning silk webs.
A predatory arachnid with eight legs and a pair of grasping pedipalps, easily recognized by its segmented tail that ends in a venomous stinger.
A small, social insect that lives in large colonies and is known for its incredible strength relative to its body size.
A small flying insect whose females pierce the skin of animals and humans to feed on blood, often transmitting diseases like malaria.
A winged beetle commonly called lightning bugs for their use of bioluminescence during twilight to attract mates or prey.
A small, round beetle with a red or orange shell and black spots, often considered a symbol of good luck.
An insect with long hind legs for leaping and mouthparts for chewing, often associated with the 'plagues' of locusts.
The larval stage of a member of the order Lepidoptera, which eventually transforms into a butterfly or moth.
A tube-shaped, segmented worm commonly found in soil, which plays a vital role in aerating and fertilizing the ground.
A slow-moving mollusk with a spiral shell that it can retract into for protection.
A bell-shaped, gelatinous marine animal with long tentacles that can deliver a painful sting.
A star-shaped echinoderm found on the sea floor, known for its ability to regenerate lost limbs.
A small marine fish with a head like a horse and a curled tail, where the males famously carry the eggs in a pouch.
A large marine crustacean with a hard shell and five pairs of legs, the first of which are large claws.
A crustacean with a broad, flat shell and ten legs, typically moving sideways.
A perennial plant with an elongated stem, or trunk, supporting branches and leaves in most species.
The seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs that are typically surrounded by brightly colored petals.
A common type of vegetation with narrow leaves that grows from the base, often covering lawns and fields.
A plant adapted to dry environments, typically having thick, fleshy stems to store water and spines instead of leaves.
The fleshy, spore-bearing fruiting body of a fungus, typically produced above ground on soil or on its food source.
A fast-growing woody grass that is a primary food source for giant pandas and is used in construction and textiles.
A flowerless plant that has feathery or leafy fronds and reproduces by spores released from the undersides of the leaves.
A small flowerless green plant that lacks true roots, growing in low tufts or damp habitats.
A simple non-flowering plant of a large group that includes seaweeds and many single-celled forms, containing chlorophyll.
The collection of eight planets and their moons in orbit around the Sun, together with smaller bodies like asteroids and comets.
The curved path of a celestial object or spacecraft around a star, planet, or moon.
The envelope of gases surrounding the Earth or another planet.
A visible mass of condensed water vapor floating in the atmosphere, typically high above the ground.
Moisture condensed from the atmosphere that falls visibly in separate drops.
Atmospheric water vapor frozen into ice crystals and falling in light white flakes.
Pellets of frozen rain that fall in showers from cumulonimbus clouds.
A loud rumbling or crashing noise heard after a lightning flash due to the expansion of rapidly heated air.
The perceptible natural movement of the air, especially in the form of a current of air blowing from a particular direction.
A thick cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the Earth's surface that obscures or restricts visibility.
Each of the four divisions of the year (spring, summer, autumn, and winter) marked by particular weather patterns and daylight hours.
A very large expanse of sea, in particular, each of the main areas into which the sea is divided geographically.
A large natural stream of water flowing in a channel to the sea, a lake, or another such stream.
A large body of water surrounded by land.
A large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level; a large steep hill.
A low area of land between hills or mountains, typically with a river or stream flowing through it.
A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it.
A natural underground chamber in a hillside or cliff.
A piece of land surrounded by water.
Any of the world's main continuous expanses of land, such as Africa, Asia, or Europe.
An imaginary line drawn around the earth equally distant from both poles, dividing the earth into northern and southern hemispheres.
The northernmost point on Earth, where the Earth's axis of rotation meets its surface.
The southernmost point on Earth, located in Antarctica.
The vast, seemingly empty region beyond Earth's atmosphere.
A person who is trained to travel in a spacecraft.
An artificial body placed in orbit around the earth or moon or another planet in order to collect information or for communication.
An unidentified flying object, especially one suspected of being a spacecraft from another planet.
A fixed luminous point in the night sky that is a large, remote incandescent body like the sun.
A celestial body moving in an elliptical orbit around a star.
A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust, held together by gravitational attraction.
All existing matter and space considered as a whole; the cosmos.
The strength and vitality required for sustained physical or mental activity, or power derived from chemical or physical resources.
A form of energy resulting from the existence of charged particles.
A piece of iron or other material that has its component atoms so ordered that the material exhibits properties of magnetism.
A solid material that is typically hard, shiny, malleable, fusible, and ductile, with good electrical and thermal conductivity.
A synthetic material made from a wide range of organic polymers that can be molded into shape while soft and then set into a rigid or slightly elastic form.
A hard, brittle substance, typically transparent or translucent, made by fusing sand with soda, lime, and sometimes other ingredients and cooling it rapidly.
A material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances.
The hard fibrous material that forms the main substance of the trunk or branches of a tree or shrub.
A soft, white, fibrous substance that surrounds the seeds of a tropical and subtropical plant and is used as textile fiber and thread for sewing.
The fine soft curly or wavy hair forming the coat of a sheep, goat, or similar animal, used for making cloth or yarn.
A fine, strong, soft lustrous fiber produced by silkworms in making cocoons and collected to make thread and fabric.
A material made from the skin of an animal by tanning or a similar process.
A tough elastic polymeric substance made from the latex of a tropical plant or synthetically.
A viscous liquid derived from petroleum, especially for use as a fuel or lubricant.
A refined petroleum used as fuel for internal combustion engines.
A combustible black or dark brown rock consisting mainly of carbonized plant matter, found mainly in underground deposits and used as fuel.
Power obtained by harnessing the energy of the sun's rays.
Power obtained by harnessing the energy of the wind.
The process of converting waste materials into new materials and objects.
The presence in or introduction into the environment of a substance or thing that has harmful or poisonous effects.
The surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.
The phenomena of the physical world collectively, including plants, animals, the landscape, and other features and products of the earth.

A warm-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that is distinguished by the possession of hair or fur, the secretion of milk by females for the nourishment of the young, and (typically) the birth of live young.
A warm-blooded egg-laying vertebrate distinguished by the possession of feathers, wings, and a beak and (typically) by being able to fly.
A limbless cold-blooded vertebrate animal with gills and fins and living wholly in water.
A vertebrate animal of a class that includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, and tortoises. They are distinguished by having a dry scaly skin and typically laying soft-shelled eggs on land.

A cold-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that comprises the frogs, toads, newts, and salamanders. They are distinguished by having an aquatic gill-breathing larval stage followed (typically) by a terrestrial lung-breathing adult stage.
A small arthropod animal that has six legs and generally one or two pairs of wings.
A stinging winged insect which collects nectar and pollen, produces wax and honey, and lives in large communities.
A domesticated carnivorous mammal that typically has a long snout, an acute sense of smell, and a barking, howling, or whining voice.
A small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractable claws.
A large plant-eating domesticated mammal with solid hoofs and a flowing mane and tail, used for riding, racing, and to pull loads.
A fully grown female animal of a domesticated breed of ox, kept to produce milk or beef.
An omnivorous domesticated hoofed mammal with sparse bristly hair and a flat snout for rooting in the soil, kept for its meat.
A domesticated ruminant animal with a thick woolly coat and (typically) horns curving backward. It is kept in flocks for its wool or meat.
A hardy domesticated ruminant animal that has hollow horns and a beard (in the male). It is kept for its milk and meat.
A domestic fowl kept for its eggs or meat, especially a young one.
A waterbird with a broad blunt bill, short legs, webbed feet, and a waddling gait.
A gregarious burrowing plant-eating mammal with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.
A hoofed grazing or browsing animal, with branched bony antlers that are shed annually and typically borne only by the male.
A large, heavy, mammal that has thick fur and a very short tail.
A wild carnivorous mammal which is the largest member of the dog family, living and hunting in packs.
A carnivorous mammal of the dog family with a pointed muzzle and bushy tail, and a reputation for being cunning.
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
A large primate that lacks a tail, including the gorilla, chimpanzees, orangutan, and gibbons.
A powerfully built great ape with a large head and short neck, found in the forests of central Africa.
A great ape with large ears, mainly black coloration and lighter skin on the face, native to the forests of west and central Africa.
A very large marine mammal with a streamlined hairless body, a horizontal tail fin, and a blowhole on top of the head for breathing.
A reptile that typically has a long body and tail, four legs, movable eyelids, and a rough, scaly, or spiny skin.
A diurnal bird of prey with broad rounded wings and a long tail.
A bird, often vividly colored, with a short hooked bill, an upright stance, and sometimes the ability to mimic human speech.
The sweet and fleshy product of a tree or other plant that contains seed and can be eaten as food.
A plant or part of a plant used as food, typically as an accompaniment to meat or fish, such as a cabbage, potato, carrot, or bean.
The expanse of salt water that covers most of the earth's surface and surrounds its landmasses.
The control center of the human body that processes information, memories, and emotions.
A muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body via the circulatory system.
The primary organs of the respiratory system used for breathing oxygen and exhaling carbon dioxide.
The internal framework of bone that supports the body and protects vital organs.
A sac-like organ in the digestive system where food is broken down by acid.
Fibrous tissue in the body that has the ability to contract, producing movement or maintaining position.
The red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins, carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues.
The largest organ of the human body that acts as a protective barrier against the environment.
The bony structure that forms the head and protects the brain.
The series of vertebrae extending from the skull to the small of the back, enclosing the spinal cord.
A pair of organs that filter waste products from the blood and produce urine.
A large organ that cleans the blood and produces bile to help with digestion.
Bundles of fibers that transmit impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord.
The smallest structural and functional unit of an organism, often called the 'building block of life.'
An invention by Alexander Graham Bell used for transmitting speech over long distances.
A global computer network providing a variety of information and communication facilities.
A device that converts sunlight into electricity for power.
An instrument measuring atmospheric pressure, used especially in forecasting the weather.
A form of electromagnetic radiation used to create images of the inside of the body, especially bones.
A substance used to stimulate the production of antibodies and provide immunity against diseases.
The first antibiotic discovered by Alexander Fleming, used to treat bacterial infections.
A type of medicine that inhibits the growth of or destroys microorganisms, especially bacteria.
A hormone produced in the pancreas which regulates the amount of glucose in the blood.
Organic compounds which are essential for normal growth and nutrition and are required in small quantities in the diet.
Essential nutrients for the human body, one of the building blocks of body tissue and can also serve as a fuel source.
Large group of organic compounds occurring in foods and living tissues and including sugars, starch, and cellulose.
A mineral that is essential for healthy bones and teeth, found in high amounts in milk and cheese.
A precious shiny grayish-white metal used in jewelry and for mirrors.
A reddish-brown metal used for electrical wiring and coins.
A lightweight, silvery-white metal used for soda cans and foil.
A heavy silvery-white metal which is liquid at ordinary temperatures, often used in old thermometers.
The first and lightest element in the periodic table, a colorless, odorless, highly flammable gas.
A light, colorless gas that does not burn, often used to make balloons float and can make your voice sound high-pitched.
The chemical element of all known life, which can take the form of graphite or diamond.
A colorless, odorless unreactive gas that forms about 78 percent of the earth's atmosphere.
A white crystalline substance, sodium chloride, used for seasoning or preserving food.
A sweet crystalline substance obtained from various plants, especially sugar cane and sugar beet.
The chemical formula for water, consisting of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.
A chemical substance with a pH less than 7, often tasting sour and capable of dissolving certain metals.
A chemical substance with a pH greater than 7, which can neutralize an acid.
The process of a liquid turning into a gas, such as water turning into steam.
The process of a gas turning into a liquid, such as water vapor forming droplets on a cold glass.
The resistance that one surface or object encounters when moving over another.
A group of atoms bonded together, representing the smallest fundamental unit of a chemical compound.
The process whereby organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
The theoretical physicist and cosmologist famous for his work on black holes and his book 'A Brief History of Time.'
A layer in the Earth's stratosphere which absorbs most of the ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth from the sun.
The trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's lower atmosphere due to the greater transparency of the atmosphere to visible radiation.
A natural fuel such as coal or gas, formed in the geological past from the remains of living organisms.
Radiant light and heat from the Sun that is harnessed using a range of technologies such as solar power to generate electricity.
A device that converts the kinetic energy of wind into electrical energy.
The variety of plant and animal life in the world or in a particular habitat, a high level of which is usually considered important and desirable.
A species of animal or plant that is seriously at risk of extinction.
The state or process of a species, family, or larger group being or becoming extinct, like the dinosaurs.
A vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.
Visible masses of condensed water vapor floating in the atmosphere, typically high above the ground.
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility (but less so than fog).
Tiny drops of water that form on cool surfaces at night, when atmospheric vapor condenses.
An astronomical event that occurs when an astronomical object or spacecraft is temporarily obscured by passing into the shadow of another body.
A celestial object consisting of a nucleus of ice and dust and, when near the sun, a ‘tail’ of gas and dust particles pointing away from the sun.
A small rocky body orbiting the sun, large numbers of which are found between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.
A small body of matter from outer space that enters the earth's atmosphere, becoming incandescent as a result of friction and appearing as a streak of light.
The prevailing cosmological model for the observable universe from the earliest known periods through its subsequent large-scale evolution.
The most extensive ring system of any planet in the Solar System, consisting of countless small particles made of water ice.
A space telescope that was launched into low Earth orbit in 1990 and remains in operation, taking iconic images of deep space.
