A modular space station in low Earth orbit, which is a collaborative project involving five participating space agencies.
The spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon, carrying astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin.
A motor vehicle that travels across the surface of the planet Mars upon arrival, used to collect information and images.
A large cat native to Africa and central Iran, it is the fastest land animal, capable of running at 80 to 128 km/h.
An arboreal herbivorous marsupial native to Australia, often called a 'bear' despite not being one.
A group of amphibians typically characterized by a lizard-like appearance, with slender bodies, blunt snouts, and short limbs.
A fast-swimming mollusk with a long body, large eyes, and ten arms, two of which are longer than the others.
A prickly bush or shrub that typically bears red, pink, yellow, or white fragrant flowers, a symbol of love.
A tall plant with a large yellow flower head that produces edible seeds and faces toward the sun.
A large tree that produces acorns and is often seen as a symbol of strength and endurance.
An evergreen coniferous tree that has needles instead of leaves and produces cones.
A tree with distinctive lobed leaves that are famous for turning bright colors in the fall and for producing syrup.
A tropical tree that has a straight unbranched trunk and a crown of large long-leafed fronds.
A fine powdery substance, typically yellow, consisting of microscopic grains discharged from the male part of a flower.
A sugary fluid secreted by plants, especially within flowers to encourage pollination by insects and birds.
The unit of reproduction of a flowering plant, capable of developing into another such plant.
The part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment.
The main woody stem of a tree as distinct from its branches and roots.
The tough, protective outer sheath of the trunk and branches of a tree.
The flattened green structures of a plant that are the main sites of photosynthesis and transpiration.
The segments of the corolla of a flower, which are modified leaves and are typically colored.
A hard stony substance secreted by certain marine polyps as an external skeleton, forming large reefs in warm seas.
Large algae growing in the sea or on rocks below the high-water mark.
The small and microscopic organisms drifting or floating in the sea or fresh water, serving as the base of the food chain.
A large extinct elephant of the Pleistocene epoch, typically hairy with long curved tusks.
An extinct large cat with massive, curved upper canine teeth.
A famous prehistoric flying reptile with a long slender head and a short tail.
Tyrannosaurus Rex, a large carnivorous dinosaur with powerful jaws and tiny arms, often called the 'king of the dinosaurs.'
A herbivorous dinosaur with three horns and a large bony frill.
The study of human history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artifacts.
The science that deals with the earth's physical structure and substance, its history, and the processes that act on it.
The study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it affects and is affected by these.
The branch of science concerned with the nature and properties of matter and energy.
The branch of science that deals with the identification of the substances of which matter is composed.
The study of living organisms and their vital processes.
The branch of science that deals with celestial objects, space, and the physical universe as a whole.
The scientific study of the human mind and its functions, especially those affecting behavior.
A room or building equipped for scientific experiments, research, or teaching.
A thin glass tube closed at one end, used to hold small amounts of material for laboratory testing or experiments.
A shallow cylindrical glass or plastic lidded dish that biologists use to culture cells or small organisms like bacteria.
A machine capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically, especially one programmable by a computer.
The theory and development of computer systems able to perform tasks that normally require human intelligence.
A remote-controlled pilotless aircraft or missile.
A rocket-launched spacecraft, able to land like an unpowered aircraft, used to make repeated journeys between earth and earth orbit.
A complex set of garments worn by astronauts to survive the harsh environment of outer space.
Molten rock that breaks through the Earth's surface during a volcanic eruption.
Molten rock that is still stored underground before it erupts as lava.
A large floating mass of ice that has broken off from a glacier and drifted into the ocean.
A large mass of snow, ice, and rocks falling rapidly down a mountainside.
Also known as Aurora Borealis, colorful light displays in the sky near the North Pole caused by solar wind.
A small piece of rock or dust from space that burns up as it enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a streak of light.
The gas that humans exhale and plants 'inhale' to make food; it is also a major greenhouse gas.
The green pigment in plants that allows them to absorb energy from sunlight.
A general term for microscopic organisms, like bacteria or viruses, that can cause disease.
A state of deep sleep or inactivity that some animals enter during the winter to conserve energy.
The seasonal movement of animals from one region to another, usually for food or breeding.
An animal that hunts and eats other animals for food.
An animal that is hunted and eaten by a predator.
An animal that eats only plants, such as a cow or a deer.
An animal that eats only meat, such as a lion or a shark.
An animal that eats both plants and meat, such as a human or a bear.
An animal that carries its underdeveloped young in a pouch, such as a kangaroo or a koala.
Animals that are active during the night and sleep during the day, such as owls and bats.
A poisonous substance injected by animals like snakes, spiders, or scorpions through a bite or sting.
The ability of an animal to blend in with its surroundings to avoid predators or hunt prey.
The respiratory organs that allow fish and other aquatic animals to breathe underwater.
Long, pointed teeth that protrude from the mouths of animals like elephants and walruses.
Bony structures that grow on the heads of deer and are shed and regrown every year.
A structure where bees live and store their honey.
A protective silk casing spun by a caterpillar before it transforms into a butterfly or moth.
The intricate structure spun by a spider to catch its prey.
The use of sound waves to locate objects, famously used by bats and dolphins.
A grassy plain in tropical and subtropical regions, with few trees, common in Africa.
A long, narrow inlet of the sea between high cliffs, formed by a submerged glacial valley.
A layer of wood produced by a tree each year; they can be counted to determine the tree's age.
The fluid that circulates through a plant, carrying nutrients.
The main body or stalk of a plant or shrub.
The small object produced by a plant from which a new plant can grow.
A pure substance made of only one type of atom, listed on the Periodic Table.
A tabular display of all known chemical elements organized by their properties.
A heavy, soft gray metal that is toxic if ingested and was once used in pipes and paint.
A heavy, radioactive element used as a fuel for nuclear power plants.
A soft form of carbon used as the 'lead' in pencils.
The temperature at which a liquid turns into a solid; for water, it is 0°C (32°F).
The temperature at which a liquid turns into a gas; for water, it is 100°C (212°F).
The speed of an object in a specific direction.
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion.
A machine that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
A device that produces a narrow, intense beam of concentrated light.
A famous space telescope that has provided some of the most detailed images of deep space.
Energy from sources that are naturally replenished, like sunlight, wind, and water.
Natural fuels like coal, oil, and gas that formed from the remains of ancient organisms.
Energy produced by splitting the nuclei of atoms, usually uranium.
A measure of how much of the Earth's resources a person or population uses.
The large-scale clearing of forests, often to make room for agriculture or urban development.
The protection and preservation of natural resources and wildlife.
Significant and long-term changes in the Earth's weather patterns and temperatures.
The state of the atmosphere at a specific time and place, including temperature and rain.
The average weather patterns in a region over a long period of time.
The process of wind or water gradually wearing away soil, rock, or land.
The regular rise and fall of the sea level caused by the gravitational pull of the Moon.
Large sections of the Earth's crust that move and interact, causing earthquakes and volcanoes.
The thin, outermost layer of the Earth.
The thick layer of hot, solid rock between the Earth's crust and its core.
The dense, extremely hot center of the Earth, made mostly of iron and nickel.
The process by which fertile land becomes desert, often due to drought or deforestation.
The artificial application of water to land or soil to help crops grow.
The transfer of pollen from one flower to another, often by bees or wind, to allow plants to reproduce.
The process of joining male and female reproductive cells to produce a new organism.
The process by which living things exchange gases with the environment to produce energy.
The process of breaking down food into smaller pieces so the body can absorb nutrients.
The movement of blood through the heart and blood vessels throughout the body.
The chemical processes that occur within a living organism to maintain life.
A chemical substance produced in the body that controls the activity of certain cells or organs.
A protein that speeds up chemical reactions in the body, like those involved in digestion.
A protein produced by the immune system to identify and neutralize harmful bacteria and viruses.
The long, coiled tubes where most of the digestion and absorption of food takes place.
An organ that produces digestive enzymes and hormones like insulin.
The muscular sac that stores urine before it is excreted from the body.
A bundle of fibers that transmits electrical impulses between the brain and the rest of the body.
An automatic and rapid physical response to a stimulus, like pulling your hand away from something hot.
The world's most famous portrait painting by Leonardo da Vinci, known for the subject's mysterious smile and housed in the Louvre.
A famous oil painting by Vincent van Gogh, featuring a swirling night sky over a small town.
A classic American novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald about the mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby and the Jazz Age.
The Dutch post-impressionist painter famous for his expressive use of color and for cutting off part of his own ear.
Shakespeare's famous tragedy about two 'star-crossed lovers' from feuding families in Verona.
The Spanish artist who co-founded the Cubist movement and is one of the most influential painters of the 20th century.
A massive 15th-century mural painting by Leonardo da Vinci representing the final meal of Jesus with his disciples.
The iconic expressionist painting by Edvard Munch showing a figure with an agonized expression against a red sky.
George Orwell's dystopian novel about a totalitarian future ruled by 'Big Brother.'
A famous bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin showing a man in deep meditation with his hand on his chin.
The English novelist known for her social commentary and romantic novels like 'Pride and Prejudice.'
Jane Austen's most famous novel, following the romance between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.
The Spanish surrealist painter known for his eccentric behavior and his painting of melting clocks.
Mary Shelley's novel about a scientist who creates a living creature from body parts, often cited as the first sci-fi story.
The founder of French Impressionist painting, famous for his series of 'Water Lilies' and 'Haystacks.'
C.S. Lewis's series of fantasy novels about children who enter a magical world through a wardrobe.
J.D. Salinger's novel about the teenage rebel Holden Caulfield, which became a staple of modern literature.
Michelangelo's masterpiece marble sculpture of the biblical hero David, located in Florence.
The Victorian-era author of classics like 'Oliver Twist,' 'A Tale of Two Cities,' and 'A Christmas Carol.'
The Charles Dickens story about the miser Ebenezer Scrooge and his transformation after being visited by three ghosts.
The Mexican painter known for her many self-portraits and her use of bold, vibrant colors.
J.R.R. Tolkien's fantasy novel following Bilbo Baggins on an adventure to reclaim a dragon's gold.
The anonymous UK-based street artist known for his satirical graffiti and political messages.
The leading figure of the Pop Art movement, famous for his prints of Campbell's Soup Cans and Marilyn Monroe.
Louisa May Alcott's novel about the lives of four sisters—Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy—growing up during the Civil War.
Paulo Coelho's international bestseller about a shepherd boy's journey to find treasure in the Egyptian pyramids.
The American artist known as the 'Mother of American Modernism,' famous for her paintings of enlarged flowers.
Homer's epic poem about the Trojan War and the hero Achilles.

word: The Diary of a Young Girl
explanation: The published journal of Anne Frank, written while she was in hiding from the Nazis in Amsterdam.
The Dutch Golden Age painter known for his use of light and shadow and his many self-portraits.
Herman Melville's novel about Captain Ahab's obsessive quest to kill a giant white whale.
The prolific American author known as the 'King of Horror,' who wrote 'It,' 'The Shining,' and 'Carrie.'

word: The Old Man and the Sea
explanation: Ernest Hemingway's short novel about an aging Cuban fisherman's battle with a giant marlin.
The American author of 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer' and 'Huckleberry Finn,' known for his humor and satire.
The fast-paced thriller by Dan Brown about a religious conspiracy involving the works of Leonardo da Vinci.
The best-selling novelist of all time, known for her detective stories featuring Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple.
The American novelist known for his adventurous life and his simple, direct writing style.
The English author of 'Animal Farm' and '1984,' known for his warnings against totalitarianism.
George Orwell's satirical novella about a group of farm animals who rebel against their human owner.
The Irish wit and playwright who wrote 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' and 'The Importance of Being Earnest.'
Oscar Wilde's novel about a man who stays young while his portrait ages and reflects his sins.
The author and illustrator of children's books featuring Peter Rabbit and other animal characters.
The beloved children's author and illustrator known for his rhyming books and characters like the Lorax.
The satirical novel by Jonathan Swift about a man who travels to remote nations, including the land of tiny people.
Leo Tolstoy's massive novel often cited as one of the greatest works of world literature, set during the Napoleonic Wars.
The famous oil painting by Dutch Golden Age painter Johannes Vermeer, featuring a girl with a large earring.
Emily Brontë's dark romantic novel about the intense love between Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff.
The American author and poet known for his tales of mystery and the macabre, such as 'The Raven.'
The famous poem by Edgar Allan Poe about a talking bird that repeatedly says 'Nevermore.'
Charles Dickens' historical novel set in London and Paris during the French Revolution.
The first part of Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy, describing the author's journey through Hell.
The Dutch painter known for his realistic domestic interiors and his masterpiece 'Girl with a Pearl Earring.'
The British children's author who wrote 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,' 'Matilda,' and 'The BFG.'
Roald Dahl's book about a boy named Charlie who wins a golden ticket to visit Willy Wonka's factory.
Roald Dahl's story about a young girl with extraordinary intelligence and telekinetic powers.
Roald Dahl's book about the 'Big Friendly Giant' who collects and delivers good dreams to children.
A style of architecture and literature characterized by pointed arches, dark settings, and supernatural themes.
An art movement that aimed to express the subconscious mind, often featuring bizarre and dreamlike imagery.
An art movement characterized by small, thin brushstrokes and the depiction of light, led by artists like Monet.
The art of beautiful writing, often using special pens or brushes.
A traditional form of Japanese poetry consisting of three lines with a 5-7-5 syllable structure.
A poem of fourteen lines using any of a number of formal rhyme schemes, famously used by Shakespeare.
A theatrical work in which a drama is set to music and sung by performers with orchestral accompaniment.
An artistic dance form performed to music using precise and highly formalized set steps and gestures.
The art of making pots, dishes, and other objects out of clay and then hardening them by baking.
A picture or pattern produced by arranging together small colored pieces of hard material, such as stone, tile, or glass.
A painting method in which the paints are made of pigments suspended in a water-based solution.
A process of painting with pigments that are held together with a medium of drying oil, like linseed oil.
The Japanese art of folding paper into decorative shapes and figures.
The art or practice of designing and constructing buildings.
A genre of literature exploring an imagined state or society in which there is great suffering or injustice.
A genre of imaginative fiction involving magic and adventure, often set in a completely different world.
A genre of fiction dealing with imaginative content such as futuristic science and technology or space travel.
A genre of fiction in which a detective or other professional solves a crime or a series of crimes.
An account of a person's life written by that person.
An account of someone's life written by someone else.
A figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.
Literary work in which special intensity is given to the expression of feelings and ideas by the use of distinctive style and rhythm.
A long, fictional narrative which describes intimate human experiences.
The main events of a play, novel, movie, or similar work, devised and presented by the writer as a sequence.
The leading character or one of the major characters in a drama, movie, novel, or other fictional text.
A person who actively opposes or is hostile to someone or something; an adversary.
A group of lines forming the basic recurring metrical unit in a poem; a verse.
Correspondence of sound between words or the endings of words, especially when these are used at the ends of lines of poetry.
A painting or other work of art executed directly on a wall.
Writing or drawings scribbled, scratched, or sprayed illicitly on a wall or other surface in a public place.
A painting or drawing of an arrangement of objects, typically including fruit and flowers and objects contrasting with these.
A painting, drawing, or photograph that depicts outdoor scenery, such as mountains, valleys, and trees.
A painting, drawing, photograph, or engraving of a person, especially one depicting only the face or head and shoulders.
A portrait of an artist produced or created by that artist.
A rough or unfinished drawing or painting, often made to assist in making a more finished picture.
A picture, description, or imitation of a person or thing in which certain striking characteristics are exaggerated for comic effect.
A medium used to express ideas by images, often combined with text or other visual information.
A novel in comic-strip format.
A book that lists words in groups of synonyms and related concepts.
A collection of myths, especially one belonging to a particular religious or cultural tradition.
A children's story about magical and imaginary beings and lands.
A short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral.
A traditional story sometimes popularly regarded as historical but unauthenticated.
A popular dance, considered as part of the tradition or custom of a particular people.
An elaborate musical composition for full orchestra, typically in four movements.
A musical composition for a solo instrument or instruments accompanied by an orchestra.
A long-lasting instrumental musical composition, usually of several movements, for one or two instruments.
A strong, regular, repeated pattern of movement or sound.
A sequence of single notes that is musically satisfying.
The combination of simultaneously sounded musical notes to produce chords and chord progressions.
The words of a song.
Writing arranged with a metrical rhythm, typically having a rhyme.
A part of a song or poem that is repeated after each verse.
A poem or song narrating a story in short stanzas.
A long poem, typically one derived from ancient oral tradition, narrating the deeds and adventures of heroic figures.
A play for theater, radio, or television.
Professional entertainment consisting of jokes and satirical sketches, intended to make an audience laugh.
A play dealing with tragic events and having an unhappy ending, especially one concerning the downfall of the main character.
The use of humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
The expression of one's meaning by using language that normally signifies the opposite, typically for humorous or emphatic effect.
An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself or regardless of any hearers, especially by a character in a play.
Commonly known as 'The Met,' it is the largest art museum in the United States, located in New York City.
A public institution in London dedicated to human history, art and culture, housing a vast collection of artifacts.
A prominent art museum located adjacent to the Piazza della Signoria in the Historic Centre of Florence.
An art museum in New York City, famous for its unique spiral design by architect Frank Lloyd Wright.

A modern art gallery located in London, it is Britain's national gallery of international modern art.
A group of museums and research centers administered by the Government of the United States.
The central district of London that is famous for its commercial theaters and entertainment.
Awards presented by the Recording Academy to recognize achievements in the music industry.
Awards that recognize excellence in live Broadway theater.
An award for achievements in newspaper, magazine, online journalism, literature, and musical composition in the United States.
A Swedish prize awarded annually since 1901 to an author from any country who has produced the most outstanding work in an ideal direction.
A book that is among those having the largest sales in a given period.
A book, movie, or work of art that is judged over a period of time to be of the highest quality and outstanding of its kind.
A work of outstanding artistry, skill, or workmanship.
A book, painting, or other creative work produced solely to make the author or artist a profit.
The exclusive legal right, given to an originator or an assignee to print, publish, perform, film, or record literary, artistic, or musical material.
The practice of taking someone else's work or ideas and passing them off as one's own.
The suppression or prohibition of any parts of books, films, or news that are considered obscene, politically unacceptable, or a threat to security.

A novel by Jane Austen, published in 1811, centered on the Dashwood sisters and their search for love.
The final novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky, focusing on a passionate philosophical debate between brothers.
A novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky about the mental anguish and moral dilemmas of an impoverished ex-student in St. Petersburg.

A landmark 1967 novel by Colombian author Gabriel García Márquez that tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family.
A novel by American writer Jack Kerouac, based on the travels of Kerouac and his friends across the United States.
A dystopian novel by Ray Bradbury, published in 1953, about a future American society where books are outlawed and 'firemen' burn any that are found.
A dystopian social science fiction novel by Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and set in a future World State.
A novel by Ayn Rand, published in 1957, which explores a dystopian United States in which many of society's most prominent and successful industrialists abandon their fortunes.
A satirical war novel by American author Joseph Heller, famous for the term it coined for a problematic situation for which the only solution is denied by a circumstance inherent in the problem.
A satirical science fiction novel by Kurt Vonnegut, which follows the life and experiences of Billy Pilgrim.
A novella written by John Steinbeck, published in 1937, which tells the story of George Milton and Lennie Small, two displaced migrant ranch workers.
An epistolary novel by American author Alice Walker which won the 1983 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.
A 1987 novel by the American writer Toni Morrison, set after the American Civil War and inspired by the life of Margaret Garner.
The debut novel by Nigerian author Chinua Achebe, first published in 1958, which depicts pre-colonial life in the southeastern part of Nigeria.
A philosophical novel by Yann Martel, published in 2001, which tells the story of a boy stranded on a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a Bengal tiger.
The first novel by Afghan-American author Khaled Hosseini, published in 2003, which tells the story of Amir and his friend Hassan.
A historical fiction novel by American author Arthur Golden, published in 1997, told from the perspective of a geisha working in Kyoto.
A 2006 post-apocalyptic novel by American writer Cormac McCarthy that details the journey of a father and his young son over a period of several months.
The iconic mascot of The Walt Disney Company, known for his red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves. He is one of the most recognizable cartoon characters in the world.
A brilliant private detective created by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, famous for his logical reasoning and use of forensic science. He lives at 221B Baker Street and is often assisted by Dr. Watson.
A DC Comics superhero from the planet Krypton who possesses incredible strength, flight, and heat vision. His secret identity is Clark Kent, a journalist for the Daily Planet.
The secret identity of Bruce Wayne, a billionaire who protects Gotham City using his high-tech gadgets and martial arts skills. He was inspired to fight crime after the tragic loss of his parents.

The superhero alter ego of Peter Parker, who gained spider-like abilities after being bitten by a radioactive spider. He is famous for his web-slinging and the motto 'With great power comes great responsibility.'
An animated rabbit from the Looney Tunes series known for his relaxed personality and his catchphrase 'What's up, doc?' He is often seen outsmarting characters like Elmer Fudd.
Steve Rogers, a super-soldier from World War II who was frozen in ice and revived in the modern day. He carries an indestructible vibranium shield and leads the Avengers.
A hobbit from the Shire who is the protagonist of 'The Lord of the Rings.' He is tasked with carrying the One Ring to Mount Doom to destroy it.
A charming smuggler and pilot of the Millennium Falcon in the Star Wars universe. He is a key hero in the Rebel Alliance and the best friend of Chewbacca.
The Snow Queen from Disney's 'Frozen,' who possesses magical powers to create ice and snow. She is famous for the song 'Let It Go' and her complex relationship with her sister, Anna.
A Marvel mutant with animal-like senses, enhanced healing abilities, and retractable adamantium claws. He is a prominent member of the X-Men.
A brilliant and studious witch who is one of Harry Potter's best friends. Her vast knowledge and mastery of spells often help her friends out of dangerous situations.
A yellow, electric-type creature and the most famous species in the Pokémon franchise. He is the loyal companion of trainer Ash Ketchum.
A powerful wizard who guides Frodo and the Fellowship in 'The Lord of the Rings.' He is known for his wisdom, his staff, and his famous line, 'You shall not pass!'
A small, green, and incredibly powerful Jedi Master in the Star Wars universe. He is known for his unique speech pattern and for training several legendary Jedi.
A young lion prince in 'The Lion King' who must overcome tragedy and reclaim his place as King of the Pride Lands. He is guided by the spirits of his father, Mufasa.
The alter ego of scientist Bruce Banner, who transforms into a giant, green-skinned monster with immense strength when he becomes angry. He is a core member of the Avengers.
A pull-string cowboy doll and the leader of Andy's toys in the 'Toy Story' films. He is loyal, brave, and initially rivals with the space ranger Buzz Lightyear.
A heroic space ranger action figure in the 'Toy Story' series. He is known for his catchphrase 'To infinity and beyond!' and his wings and laser beam.

A bitter, green creature created by Dr. Seuss who hates Christmas and attempts to steal it from the residents of Whoville. His heart eventually grows three sizes when he learns the true meaning of the holiday.
The human protagonist of the 'Twilight' series who falls in love with a vampire named Edward Cullen. Her story focuses on the dangerous romance between her world and the supernatural.
A handsome and immortal vampire in the 'Twilight' saga who chooses to live off animal blood rather than human. He is deeply protective of his human love, Bella Swan.
A hobbit who is the title character of J.R.R. Tolkien's 'The Hobbit.' He unexpectedly finds the One Ring during an adventure with dwarves and the wizard Gandalf.
A protocol droid fluent in over six million forms of communication in the Star Wars universe. He is almost always accompanied by his droid companion, R2-D2.
An astromech droid and a courageous hero in the Star Wars films. He communicates through beeps and whistles and has saved the lives of his human friends many times.
Charlie Brown's pet beagle in the 'Peanuts' comic strip, known for his rich fantasy life and for sleeping on top of his doghouse. He is often seen as a World War I flying ace.
The lovable loser and central character of the 'Peanuts' comic strip. He is known for his 'good grief' catchphrase and his zig-zag shirt.
A creature from 'The Lord of the Rings' whose mind and body were twisted by the influence of the One Ring. He is famous for his raspy voice and calling the ring his 'precious.'
A young girl who falls down a rabbit hole into Wonderland, where she encounters many nonsensical characters. Her journey is a classic tale of curiosity and growing up.
A colorful and eccentric character in 'Alice in Wonderland' who is perpetually trapped in a tea party. He is known for his riddle: 'Why is a raven like a writing desk?'
A tall, hairy Wookiee and the loyal co-pilot and best friend of Han Solo in Star Wars. He communicates through growls and is a skilled mechanic and warrior.
Natasha Romanoff, a highly trained former Soviet spy and assassin who becomes a core member of the Avengers. She is a master of martial arts and espionage.
The primary antagonist of the Harry Potter series, a dark wizard who seeks to achieve immortality and pure-blood supremacy. He is often referred to as 'He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.'
The wise and powerful Headmaster of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. He is a mentor to Harry Potter and the leader of the Order of the Phoenix.
Harry Potter's loyal and humorous best friend, who comes from a large family of wizards. He is known for his red hair and his fear of spiders.
A centuries-old vampire nobleman from Transylvania created by Bram Stoker. He is the most famous vampire in literature and film, known for his ability to transform into a bat.
The creature brought to life from various body parts by the scientist Victor Frankenstein. He is often misunderstood and struggles with his identity and the rejection of humanity.
A giant, prehistoric ape from Skull Island who becomes fascinated with a human woman. He is famously captured and brought to New York, where he climbs the Empire State Building.
A giant, prehistoric sea monster awakened and empowered by nuclear radiation. He is a pop culture icon from Japan, often depicted as both a destructive force and a protector.
A gentle and highly intelligent alien who becomes stranded on Earth and befriends a young boy named Elliott. He is known for his glowing finger and the phrase 'E.T. phone home.'
The mother of the future resistance leader in the 'Terminator' films. She transforms from a regular waitress into a fierce warrior to protect her son and stop Judgment Day.
The protagonist of 'The Matrix' trilogy, a computer hacker who discovers he is 'The One' destined to free humanity from a simulated reality. He is known for his trench coat and 'bullet time' moves.
The captain of the Nebuchadnezzar in 'The Matrix' and a mentor to Neo. He is the one who offers Neo the choice between the red pill and the blue pill.
A skilled computer hacker and high-ranking officer in the human resistance in 'The Matrix.' She is a key ally and love interest to Neo.
The heroic lawyer from 'To Kill a Mockingbird' who defends a Black man wrongly accused of a crime. He is an enduring symbol of integrity and moral courage.
The loyal friend and biographer of Sherlock Holmes. As a medical doctor and former military officer, he often provides a grounded perspective to Holmes' brilliant deductions.
The curious and spirited protagonist of Disney's 'The Little Mermaid.' She is a mermaid princess who dreams of living on land and eventually marries Prince Eric.
A young woman who loves books and adventure in Disney's 'Beauty and the Beast.' She sees beyond the Beast's terrifying appearance to find the prince hidden within.
The independent and strong-willed princess of Agrabah who longs to see the world beyond the palace walls. She eventually falls in love with the kind-hearted Aladdin.
The energetic and comical blue spirit from the magic lamp in 'Aladdin.' He is famously voiced by Robin Williams and has 'phenomenal cosmic powers.'
The hardworking and ambitious protagonist of Disney's 'The Princess and the Frog.' She dreams of opening her own restaurant in New Orleans.
A princess with seventy feet of magical, glowing golden hair who has been locked in a tower her whole life. She escapes with a thief named Flynn Rider to see the lanterns on her birthday.
The 'fairest of them all' from Disney's first animated feature. She escapes her evil stepmother and takes refuge with seven dwarfs in the forest.
The protagonist of 'Sleeping Beauty,' also known as Briar Rose. She is cursed to prick her finger on a spinning wheel and fall into a deep sleep that can only be broken by true love's kiss.
The bumbling and dim-witted patriarch of the Griffin family in 'Family Guy.' He often gets into absurd and hilarious situations in the town of Quahog.
The highly intelligent, articulate, and often diabolical baby of the Griffin family in 'Family Guy.' He possesses advanced technology and a British accent.
The Griffin family's anthropomorphic dog in 'Family Guy,' who is an aspiring writer and often the voice of reason. He is close friends with Stewie.
The spoiled, loud-mouthed, and manipulative fourth-grader from 'South Park.' He is one of the most famous and controversial characters in television history.
One of the main protagonists of 'South Park,' often portrayed as the most grounded and moral member of the group. He is known for his blue and red hat.
A moral and intelligent fourth-grader in 'South Park' who often serves as the rival to Eric Cartman. He is recognizable by his green ushanka hat.
A character in 'South Park' famous for being muffled by his orange parka and for dying in almost every episode during the show's early seasons.
Scooby-Doo's best friend and fellow coward, known for his green shirt, messy hair, and enormous appetite. He is often the first to run from danger.
The leader of the Mystery Inc. gang in 'Scooby-Doo,' known for driving the Mystery Machine and setting elaborate traps to catch villains.
A member of the Mystery Inc. gang in 'Scooby-Doo,' often depicted as the fashion-conscious 'damsel in distress' who later became a capable martial artist.
The highly intelligent and skeptical member of the Mystery Inc. gang who usually solves the mystery. She is recognizable by her orange sweater and glasses.
The brilliant but cynical and alcoholic mad scientist from 'Rick and Morty.' He travels through the multiverse with his grandson, Morty, causing chaos wherever he goes.
The anxious and good-hearted grandson of Rick Sanchez in 'Rick and Morty.' He is frequently dragged into dangerous interdimensional adventures.
One of Disney's most famous characters, a white duck with a yellow-orange bill and feet. He is known for his short temper and unintelligible speech.
A tall, anthropomorphic dog who is one of Mickey Mouse's best friends. He is known for his clumsiness, his unique laugh, and his signature catchphrase 'Gawrsh!'
A muscular sailor character known for eating spinach to gain superhuman strength. He is often seen protecting his girlfriend, Olive Oyl, from the villain Bluto.
A famous animated character from the 1930s, known for her oversized head and short dress. She is a classic symbol of the Jazz Age.
The main character of 'The Flintstones,' a Stone Age family man who lives in the town of Bedrock. He is famous for his catchphrase 'Yabba Dabba Doo!'
Fred's patient and level-headed wife in 'The Flintstones.' She is the mother of Pebbles and a close friend to their neighbors, the Rubbles.
Fred Flintstone's best friend and neighbor in 'The Flintstones.' He is often the sidekick to Fred's get-rich-quick schemes.
The wife of Barney Rubble and Wilma's best friend in 'The Flintstones.' She is the mother of Bamm-Bamm.
The patriarch of the Jetson family in the futuristic animated series 'The Jetsons.' He works for Spacely Space Sprockets and lives in a world of flying cars.
A lovable and 'silly old bear' created by A.A. Milne, known for his love of honey and his friends in the Hundred Acre Wood.
Winnie the Pooh's timid but loyal best friend, a small pig who is often afraid but manages to be brave for his friends.
An energetic and bouncy stuffed tiger in the Hundred Acre Wood. He is famous for his enthusiasm and saying 'T-I-double-G-er!'
A pessimistic and gloomy stuffed donkey in the Hundred Acre Wood. He often loses his tail and is known for his slow speech and sad outlook.
The young boy who is the owner and friend of the stuffed animals in the Hundred Acre Wood, including Winnie the Pooh.
A polite bear from Darkest Peru who travels to London and is adopted by the Brown family. He is famous for his blue coat, red hat, and love of marmalade.
The incredibly wealthy uncle of Donald Duck, known for his stinginess and for swimming in his vault of gold coins.
A cool and sophisticated animated panther who originally appeared in the opening titles of the film series of the same name.
A lazy, orange tabby cat known for his love of lasagna and his hatred of Mondays. He often teases his owner Jon and the dog Odie.
A legendary Greek hero and king of Ithaca, the protagonist of Homer's epic poem the Odyssey. He is famous for his intelligence and his ten-year journey home after the Trojan War.
The mysterious and wealthy protagonist of F. Scott Fitzgerald's 'The Great Gatsby,' known for his lavish parties and his tragic obsession with Daisy Buchanan.
A character created by Mark Twain who travels down the Mississippi River on a raft. His story explores themes of freedom and the flaws of society.
A mischievous boy living in the fictional town of St. Petersburg, Missouri, in the novels of Mark Twain. He is famous for tricking others into whitewashing a fence.
The protagonist of Victor Hugo's 'Les Misérables,' a man who spends nineteen years in prison for stealing a loaf of bread and later seeks redemption.
The author of 'Frankenstein,' often credited with creating the science fiction genre. She wrote the novel when she was only nineteen years old.
The miserly protagonist of Charles Dickens' 'A Christmas Carol' who is transformed into a kinder man after being visited by three ghosts on Christmas Eve.
The title character of Charles Dickens' novel, an orphan boy who escapes a workhouse and joins a group of pickpockets in London.
The protagonist of Daniel Defoe's novel who survives for twenty-eight years on a remote desert island after a shipwreck.
The protagonist of Jonathan Swift's 'Gulliver's Travels,' a ship's surgeon who travels to several fantastical lands, including Lilliput, the land of tiny people.
A Spanish nobleman who becomes obsessed with tales of chivalry and decides to become a knight-errant. He is famous for 'tilting at windmills' that he believes are giants.
A mysterious and disfigured musical genius who haunts the Paris Opera House. He becomes obsessed with a young soprano named Christine Daaé.
The enigmatic and brilliant captain of the submarine Nautilus in Jules Verne's 'Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.'
A mischievous young rabbit created by Beatrix Potter, known for his blue jacket and for sneaking into Mr. McGregor's garden.
The beautiful and noble queen consort of King Arthur in Arthurian legend. Her tragic love affair with the knight Lancelot is a central theme of the story.
One of the greatest and most famous Knights of the Round Table in Arthurian legend. He is known for his skill in battle and his devotion to Queen Guinevere.
The legendary giant white whale in Herman Melville's novel, which becomes the object of Captain Ahab's obsessive quest for revenge.
The vengeful and obsessive captain of the whaling ship Pequod in 'Moby Dick,' who lost his leg to the titular white whale.
The protagonist of Nathaniel Hawthorne's 'The Scarlet Letter,' a woman forced to wear the letter 'A' as punishment for adultery.
The spirited and independent protagonist of Louisa May Alcott's 'Little Women,' who dreams of becoming a writer.
The intelligent and witty protagonist of Jane Austen's 'Pride and Prejudice,' who eventually falls in love with Mr. Darcy.
The wealthy and initially proud romantic lead of 'Pride and Prejudice.' His transformation and devotion to Elizabeth Bennet are central to the novel.
The protagonist of Oscar Wilde's 'The Picture of Dorian Gray,' a man who remains young and beautiful while his portrait ages and reflects his moral decay.
The alienated teenage protagonist of J.D. Salinger's 'The Catcher in the Rye,' who has become a symbol of adolescent rebellion.
The young narrator of 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' who observes the events of her town through an innocent lens as she grows up.
The mysterious and reclusive neighbor in 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' who becomes a figure of both fear and curiosity for the local children.
The primary antagonist of 'Peter Pan,' a pirate captain who seeks revenge on Peter for cutting off his hand and feeding it to a crocodile.
A small and feisty fairy who is the companion of Peter Pan. She is known for her fairy dust, which allows people to fly.
The 'Mistress of All Evil' and the villain of Disney's 'Sleeping Beauty,' who curses the infant Princess Aurora. She was later reimagined as a misunderstood protagonist.
The fashion-obsessed villain of '101 Dalmatians,' known for her black and white hair and her desire to make a coat out of Dalmatian fur.
The villainous sea witch in 'The Little Mermaid' who makes a deal with Ariel to take her voice in exchange for human legs.
The villain of 'The Lion King,' the brother of King Mufasa who plots to take the throne for himself. He is known for his dark mane and his manipulative nature.
The primary villain of 'The Wizard of Oz,' who seeks to recover the ruby slippers from Dorothy. She is famous for her green skin and flying monkeys.
The young girl from Kansas who is transported to the magical Land of Oz. She is famous for her blue gingham dress and her ruby slippers.
One of Dorothy's companions in 'The Wizard of Oz' who is in search of a brain. He is made of straw and is a loyal friend to Dorothy.
A companion of Dorothy in 'The Wizard of Oz' who is in search of a heart. He is made entirely of tin and must be oiled to keep from rusting.
A companion of Dorothy in 'The Wizard of Oz' who is in search of courage. Despite his fears, he often manages to be brave for his friends.
A large and friendly forest spirit in the Studio Ghibli film 'My Neighbor Totoro.' He has become an iconic symbol of Japanese animation.
The protagonist of the popular anime series of the same name, a schoolgirl who transforms into a powerful sailor soldier to protect the Earth.
The protagonist of the 'Dragon Ball' series, a powerful warrior who protects the Earth from various threats. He is known for his incredible strength and his signature 'Kamehameha' move.
The protagonist of the 'Naruto' anime, a young ninja who dreams of becoming the leader of his village. He is known for his orange jumpsuit and his determination.
The protagonist of 'One Piece,' a young man with a rubber body who dreams of becoming the King of the Pirates. He is known for his straw hat and his optimistic personality.
The main protagonist of the 'Pokémon' anime series, a young trainer who dreams of becoming a Pokémon Master alongside his partner, Pikachu.
The protagonist of 'The Legend of Zelda' video game series, a young hero who often rescues Princess Zelda and saves the land of Hyrule from the villain Ganon.
The wise and often magical princess of Hyrule in 'The Legend of Zelda' series. She is a recurring character who often aids Link in his quests.
The primary antagonist of the Super Mario series, a large, fire-breathing turtle-like creature who frequently kidnaps Princess Peach.
The princess of the Mushroom Kingdom in the Super Mario series. She is a recurring character who is often rescued by Mario but also appears as a playable hero.
The protagonist of the 'Metroid' series, an intergalactic bounty hunter who wears a powerful exosuit. She was one of the first major female protagonists in video games.
The protagonist of 'The Witcher' series, a mutated monster hunter for hire. He is known for his silver hair and his ability to use magical 'signs.'
One of the protagonists of 'The Last of Us' video games, a teenage girl who is immune to the fungal infection that has devastated humanity.
One of the protagonists of 'The Last of Us,' a survivor who is tasked with escorting Ellie across the post-apocalyptic United States.
The protagonist of the 'Uncharted' series, a charismatic treasure hunter who travels the world uncovering historical mysteries.
A small purple dragon who is the protagonist of his own video game series, known for his ability to breathe fire and charge at enemies.
The energetic and slightly crazed bandicoot who is the mascot of his own series of platforming video games.
The protagonist of 'Final Fantasy VII,' a mercenary with a massive sword who becomes involved in a rebellion against a powerful corporation.
The iconic and powerful antagonist of 'Final Fantasy VII,' a former hero who becomes a threat to the world.
A skilled martial artist and a key ally of Cloud Strife in 'Final Fantasy VII.' She is known for her strength and her kind nature.
The primary antagonist of 'Masters of the Universe,' a powerful sorcerer with a skull-like face who seeks to conquer Castle Grayskull.
The noble and powerful leader of the Autobots in the 'Transformers' franchise, who can transform into a semi-truck.
The ruthless and powerful leader of the Decepticons in the 'Transformers' franchise, who seeks to conquer Cybertron and Earth.
A loyal and courageous Autobot in the 'Transformers' franchise, known for his small size and his ability to transform into a yellow car.
The leader of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, who wears a blue mask and wields two katanas. He is known for his discipline and tactical mind.
The highly intelligent and inventive member of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, who wears a purple mask and wields a bo staff.
The tough and hot-headed member of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, who wears a red mask and wields two sai.
The wise and skilled rat who is the father and sensei of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, teaching them the art of ninjutsu.
The dim-witted but lovable pink starfish who is the best friend of SpongeBob SquarePants. He lives under a rock and is known for his incredible appetite and lack of common sense.
The grumpy, clarinet-playing neighbor of SpongeBob who works as a cashier at the Krusty Krab. He considers himself an artist and is frequently annoyed by SpongeBob and Patrick.
The money-obsessed crab who owns the Krusty Krab restaurant. He is the father of a whale named Pearl and the employer of SpongeBob and Squidward.
The central character of 'Stranger Things,' a young girl with powerful psychokinetic abilities who was raised in a mysterious laboratory. she is known for her love of Eggo waffles.

A key protagonist in 'Game of Thrones,' known for his honor and leadership as a member of the Night's Watch. He is often associated with his direwolf, Ghost, and the phrase 'You know nothing, Jon Snow.'
The 'Mother of Dragons' in 'Game of Thrones' who seeks to reclaim the Iron Throne. She is famous for her three dragons and her long list of titles.
A witty and highly intelligent character from 'Game of Thrones' known for his love of wine and books. Despite his small stature, he is one of the most politically powerful players in Westeros.
The eccentric and often inappropriate Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin in the US version of 'The Office.' He is known for his catchphrase 'That's what she said.'
A beet farmer and top salesman at Dunder Mifflin known for his intense personality and strict adherence to rules. He is the Assistant to the Regional Manager and a black belt in karate.
A salesman at Dunder Mifflin known for his pranks on Dwight and his long-running romance with the receptionist, Pam. He often looks directly at the camera to share his reactions to office antics.
The receptionist at Dunder Mifflin who eventually marries Jim Halpert. She is an aspiring artist and one of the most grounded characters in 'The Office.'
A highly intelligent but socially inept theoretical physicist in 'The Big Bang Theory.' He is known for his strict routines, his love of comic books, and his catchphrase 'Bazinga!'
A character from 'How I Met Your Mother' known for his expensive suits, his elaborate 'playbook' for picking up women, and his catchphrase 'Legen-dary!'
The powerful villain of the Marvel Cinematic Universe who seeks to collect all six Infinity Stones to wipe out half of all life in the universe with a snap of his fingers.
A tree-like creature from 'Guardians of the Galaxy' who is known for only saying the phrase 'I am Groot.' He is a loyal member of the team and can regrow his limbs.
A genetically engineered, fast-talking raccoon who is a master of weapons and explosives. He is a key member of the Guardians of the Galaxy.
A former psychiatrist who becomes the Joker's accomplice and girlfriend. She is known for her acrobatic skills, her colorful hair, and her giant mallet or baseball bat.
The title held by several different sidekicks of Batman, most notably Dick Grayson. He is a highly skilled acrobat and crime-fighter who assists Batman in Gotham City.
Selina Kyle, a skilled cat burglar in Gotham City who has a complicated love-hate relationship with Batman. She is known for her whip and her cat-themed costume.
The friendly and innocent enchanted snowman from Disney's 'Frozen' who loves warm hugs. He provides comic relief and is a loyal friend to Anna and Elsa.
Also known as Experiment 626, a blue, mischievous alien creature who is adopted as a dog by a young Hawaiian girl named Lilo.
The protagonist of the 'Cars' films, a red race car who learns about humility and the importance of friendship in the small town of Radiator Springs.
The main character of 'Despicable Me,' a supervillain who softens after adopting three orphan girls. He leads a massive army of yellow Minions.
Small, yellow, cylindrical creatures from 'Despicable Me' who serve evil masters. They are famous for their unique language and their love of bananas.
The protagonist of 'Kung Fu Panda,' a clumsy panda who is unexpectedly chosen as the Dragon Warrior to protect his valley through the art of kung fu.
A rare Night Fury dragon in 'How to Train Your Dragon' who befriends a young Viking named Hiccup, changing the way humans and dragons interact.
A legendary Jedi Master who mentors both Anakin and Luke Skywalker in the Star Wars universe. He is known for his wisdom and his mastery of the lightsaber.
A fearless leader in the Rebel Alliance and the twin sister of Luke Skywalker. She is one of the most iconic female characters in sci-fi history.
The mysterious Potions Master at Hogwarts in the Harry Potter series. He is a complex character whose true loyalties are a major mystery throughout the story.
The giant and kind-hearted Gamekeeper at Hogwarts who introduces Harry Potter to the wizarding world. He has a great love for dangerous magical creatures.
A house-elf who becomes a loyal friend to Harry Potter. He is known for his selfless devotion and for being freed from his cruel masters with a sock.
Harry Potter's rival at Hogwarts and a member of the Slytherin house. He comes from a wealthy, 'pure-blood' wizarding family that supports Lord Voldemort.
Simba's father and the original King of the Pride Lands. He is a wise and powerful leader who appears as a spirit to guide his son.
The comedic meerkat and warthog duo who adopt Simba and teach him their philosophy of 'Hakuna Matata,' meaning 'no worries.'
The primary emotion inside the mind of the young girl Riley in Disney-Pixar's 'Inside Out.' She is a glowing, energetic character who strives to keep Riley happy.
The small, green, one-eyed monster from 'Monsters, Inc.' who is the best friend and business partner of Sulley. He is a fast talker and a skilled comedian.
James P. Sullivan, a large, furry blue monster and the top 'scarer' at Monsters, Inc. He becomes the protector of a human girl named Boo.
A young clownfish with a small fin who is captured by divers, sparking a massive search by his father across the ocean in 'Finding Nemo.'
A friendly and optimistic blue tang fish who suffers from short-term memory loss. She helps Marlin find his son Nemo and later stars in her own sequel.
An inflatable healthcare companion robot from 'Big Hero 6' who becomes a superhero to help his friend Hiro and his team.
Bob Parr, the patriarch of the superpowered Parr family in 'The Incredibles.' He possesses superhuman strength and struggles with a mundane life when superheroes are banned.
Helen Parr, the wife of Mr. Incredible, who can stretch and reshape her body in extraordinary ways. She is a capable leader and protective mother.
The baby of the Parr family in 'The Incredibles' who possesses a wide and unpredictable range of powerful superhuman abilities.
The eccentric and diminutive fashion designer for superheroes in 'The Incredibles,' known for her strict 'no capes' rule.
A brave young boy and the main protagonist of 'Adventure Time,' who travels through the Land of Ooo fighting monsters and helping people.
Finn's magical best friend and adoptive brother in 'Adventure Time.' He can stretch, shrink, and mold his body into any shape.
The tragic and misunderstood antagonist of 'Adventure Time,' an old wizard who wears a magical crown that gives him ice powers but also makes him lose his mind.
The terrifying ancient creature from Stephen King's 'It' that primarily takes the form of a dancing clown to lure and prey on children.
A powerful and intelligent villain in the Batman universe who is known for his physical strength and for being the man who 'broke the bat' by injuring Batman's back.
The billionaire business mogul and brilliant scientist who is Superman's greatest arch-nemesis. He views Superman as a threat to humanity's potential.
The superhero identity of Hal Jordan (and others), a member of an intergalactic police force who uses a power ring to create physical constructs from green energy.
Oswald Cobblepot, a sophisticated and umbrella-wielding crime boss in Gotham City who is one of Batman's oldest enemies.
Edward Nygma, a Batman villain who is obsessed with riddles, puzzles, and word games, often leaving clues for the police and Batman at his crime scenes.
Harvey Dent, the former District Attorney of Gotham City who was disfigured on one side of his face. He becomes a criminal who decides his actions by flipping a coin.
Charles Xavier, the powerful telepathic founder of the X-Men who runs a school for mutants and advocates for peaceful coexistence between humans and mutants.
The powerful mutant with the ability to manipulate magnetic fields. He is the rival and occasional ally of Professor X, believing that mutants should rule over humans.
A powerful mutant and member of the X-Men who can control the weather and fly. She is often depicted as a goddess and a leader.
A mutant shape-shifter who can take on the appearance and voice of anyone. She is a frequent antagonist and ally in the X-Men series.
Wanda Maximoff, a powerful Marvel character with the ability to manipulate reality and use chaos magic. She is a central figure in the Avengers and the series 'WandaVision.'
The globally famous fictional character produced by the Japanese company Sanrio, known for her red bow and her lack of a mouth.
The default player character in the world-building game 'Minecraft.' He is iconic for his blue shirt and his ability to mine and craft almost anything.
The friendly green dinosaur from the Super Mario series who often serves as a mount for Mario. He can eat enemies with his long tongue and turn them into eggs.
The mushroom-headed attendant of Princess Peach in the Mushroom Kingdom. He is a recurring character who often provides help to Mario.
Mario's greedy and exaggerated rival, known for his yellow hat, purple overalls, and large 'W' on his cap. He often stars in his own treasure-hunting adventures.

The study of past events, particularly in human affairs.

To convert information into a code or cipher, typically to prevent unauthorized access.

A high-capacity transmission technique using a wide range of frequencies, which enables a large number of messages to be communicated simultaneously.
The state of being protected against the criminal or unauthorized use of electronic data, or the measures taken to achieve this.

word: The ball is in your court
explanation: An idiom meaning it is up to you to make the next decision or step.
An idiom meaning to avoid saying what one means directly, usually because the topic is uncomfortable.
An idiom referring to a misfortune that eventually results in something good happening later on.
An idiom meaning to do something that makes it impossible to return to the previous situation or relationship.

word: By the skin of your teeth
explanation: An idiom meaning to just barely succeed in doing something.
An idiom meaning to give a false alarm.
An idiom meaning to do something perfunctorily or incompletely in order to save time or money.
An idiom referring to a major problem or controversial issue that is present but everyone is ignoring.
An idiom meaning to get out of control.
An idiom used to tell someone to not give up.

word: Hit the nail on the head
explanation: An idiom meaning to describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem.
An idiom referring to the last in a series of bad things that happens to make someone very angry or give up.
An idiom meaning to allow someone who has been caught doing something wrong to go without being punished.
An idiom meaning it's too late; to miss an opportunity.
An idiom meaning you have to work hard for what you want.
An idiom meaning to be alert and aware of what is happening.
An idiom meaning to joke with someone by telling them something that isn't true.
An idiom used when the person you have just been talking about arrives.
An idiom meaning to understand something complicated.

word: Your guess is as good as mine
explanation: An idiom meaning I have no idea.

word: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
explanation: A proverb meaning it is better to keep what you have than to risk losing it by trying to get something better.

word: A penny saved is a penny earned
explanation: A proverb used to emphasize the importance of saving money.
A proverb meaning that what you do is more significant than what you say.

word: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
explanation: A proverb meaning that different people have different ideas about what is beautiful.
A proverb used to say that even though something is late, it is better than if it had not happened at all.

word: Don't judge a book by its cover
explanation: A proverb meaning you shouldn't form an opinion on someone or something based solely on their appearance.
A proverb meaning that something that is easily won may also be easily lost.

word: Every cloud has a silver lining
explanation: A proverb used to say that every bad situation has some good aspect to it.
A proverb meaning that it is always better to tell the truth.
A proverb meaning that if you do something regularly, you will become very good at it.
The world's most popular sport, played between two teams of eleven players with a spherical ball on a rectangular field with a goal at each end.
A game played between two teams of five players on a rectangular court, where the goal is to shoot a ball through a hoop elevated ten feet high.
A racket sport that can be played individually against a single opponent or between two teams of two players each on a rectangular court divided by a net.
A club-and-ball sport in which players use various clubs to hit balls into a series of holes on a course in as few strokes as possible.
A team sport played by two teams of eleven players on a rectangular field with goalposts at each end, known for its strategic plays and physical contact.
A bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding, with the goal of scoring runs by hitting a ball and running around four bases.
A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players on a field at the center of which is a 22-yard pitch, extremely popular in Commonwealth nations.
A team sport played with an oval ball that may be kicked, carried, and passed from hand to hand, known for its intense scrums and lack of protective padding compared to American football.
A combat sport in which two people, usually wearing protective gloves, throw punches at each other for a set amount of time in a square ring.
The highest class of international racing for open-wheel single-seater formula racing cars, featuring legendary drivers and high-tech vehicles.
A leading international sporting event featuring summer and winter sports competitions in which thousands of athletes from around the world participate.
The premier international association football competition contested by the senior men's national teams of the members of FIFA every four years.
The annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL), famous for its massive viewership, expensive commercials, and halftime show.
The oldest and most prestigious tennis tournament in the world, held in London and played on traditional grass courts.
An annual men's multiple-stage bicycle race primarily held in France, known as the most difficult and prestigious cycling race in the world.
An individual or team racing sport that requires the use of one's entire body to move through water, featured heavily in the Summer Olympics.
A sport that includes physical exercises requiring balance, strength, flexibility, agility, coordination, and endurance, often performed on apparatus like the balance beam.
A contact team sport played on ice, usually in a rink, in which two teams of skaters use their sticks to shoot a vulcanized rubber puck into their opponent's net.
A team sport in which two teams of six players are separated by a net, and each team tries to score points by grounding a ball on the opponent's side.
A racket sport played using rackets to hit a shuttlecock across a net, which can be played as singles or doubles.
Also known as ping-pong, a sport in which two or four players hit a lightweight ball back and forth across a table using small rackets.
The use of bicycles for transport, recreation, exercise, or sport, encompassing disciplines like road racing, mountain biking, and track cycling.
A surface water pastime in which the wave rider, referred to as a surfer, rides on the forward face of a moving wave on a surfboard.
An action sport that involves riding and performing tricks using a skateboard, recently added as an Olympic sport.
A recreational activity and Olympic sport that involves descending a snow-covered slope while standing on a board attached to a rider's feet.
The action of traveling over snow on skis, especially as a sport or recreation, including downhill and cross-country disciplines.
Various systems of training for combat, such as karate, judo, or taekwondo, practiced for self-defense, sport, or mental development.
Mixed Martial Arts, a full-contact combat sport that allows a wide variety of fighting techniques and skills from a mixture of other combat sports.
A combat sport involving grappling-type techniques such as clinch fighting, throws and takedowns, joint locks, and pins.
The sport, practice, or skill of using a bow to shoot arrows at a target.
A competitive sport in which small missiles are thrown at a circular target called a dartboard fixed to a wall.
A target sport and recreational activity in which a player rolls a ball toward pins or another relevant target.
A variety of games played on a rectangular table with a designated number of small balls and a long stick called a cue.
A board game for two players, sometimes classified as a 'mind sport,' played on a checkered board with the goal of checkmating the opponent's king.
A method of terrestrial locomotion allowing humans and other animals to move rapidly on foot, practiced competitively in track and field events.
A long-distance foot race with a distance of 26.2 miles, usually run as a road race.
An endurance multisport race consisting of swimming, cycling, and running in immediate succession over various distances.
The sport of racing boats using oars, involving teams of varying sizes, often seen in the famous Oxford-Cambridge boat race.
The sport or activity of using boats with sails to travel across water, utilizing the wind to propel the vessel.
Sports related to horse riding, including disciplines such as dressage, show jumping, and eventing.
An equestrian performance sport, typically involving two or more horses ridden by jockeys over a set distance for competition.
A team sport played on horseback in which the objective is to score goals against an opposing team using a long-handled mallet to hit a small ball.
A group of three related combat sports using bladed weapons: the foil, the épée, and the sabre.
A team sport played with a lacrosse stick and a lacrosse ball, where players use the head of the stick to carry, pass, and shoot the ball into a goal.
A team sport in which two teams of seven players each pass a ball using their hands with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the other team.
A team sport played on grass or turf with a stick and a hard ball, where players try to score by hitting the ball into the opponent's net.
A sport in which players slide stones on a sheet of ice toward a target area, which is segmented into four concentric circles.
A sport in which individuals, pairs, or groups perform on figure skates on ice, known for its jumps, spins, and artistic presentation.
A racket and ball sport played by two or four players in a four-walled court with a small, hollow rubber ball.
The activity of using one's hands, feet, or any other part of the body to ascend a steep topographical object, such as a rock face or an indoor wall.
The activity of catching fish, either for food or as a sport, often using a rod, line, and hook.
The practice of seeking, pursuing, and capturing or killing wild animals, often practiced as a sport.
A group of physical, mental, and spiritual practices or disciplines which originated in ancient India, often involving stretching and meditation.
A physical fitness system developed in the early 20th century, focused on improving flexibility, strength, and body awareness through controlled movements.
A sport in which the athlete attempts a maximum-weight single lift of a barbell loaded with weight plates.
The use of progressive resistance exercise to control and develop one's muscles for aesthetic purposes.
A branded fitness regimen that involves constantly varied functional movements performed at high intensity.
A spherical ball used in the sport of football, typically featuring a black-and-white pentagonal pattern.
A horizontal circular metal rim with a net hanging from it, mounted to a backboard and used for scoring points.
A handled tool with a frame and a tightly stretched network of strings used for hitting a tennis ball.
An implement used to hit a golf ball, consisting of a shaft with a grip and a clubhead, coming in types like woods, irons, and putters.

A British explorer and captain in the Royal Navy who made three voyages to the Pacific Ocean. He is famous for his detailed maps of Newfoundland and for being the first European to contact the eastern coastline of Australia.
A Russian writer who is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time. He is best known for the epic novels 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina.'

A Russian novelist and philosopher whose works explore human psychology in the troubled political and social atmospheres of 19th-century Russia. He wrote 'Crime and Punishment' and 'The Brothers Karamazov.'
A French poet and novelist of the Romantic movement. He is considered one of the greatest French writers and is best known for 'Les Misérables' and 'The Hunchback of Notre-Dame.'

A prolific French writer whose works have been translated into nearly 100 languages. He is famous for his historical novels of adventure, including 'The Three Musketeers' and 'The Count of Monte Cristo.'
A Danish author remembered for his literary fairy tales. His most famous stories include 'The Little Mermaid,' 'The Ugly Duckling,' and 'The Snow Queen.'
Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm were German academics and authors who specialized in collecting and publishing folklore. They are famous for 'Grimm's Fairy Tales,' including 'Cinderella' and 'Snow White.'
The pen name of English author Charles Lutwidge Dodgson. He is best known for his children's fiction, especially 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' and its sequel 'Through the Looking-Glass.'
A Norwegian painter and printmaker whose best-known work, 'The Scream,' has become one of the most iconic images of world art. His work focused on themes of anxiety, death, and love.
A Canadian singer-songwriter and painter whose work is highly influential in folk and rock music. She is famous for her album 'Blue' and songs like 'Big Yellow Taxi' and 'Both Sides Now.'
An American agricultural scientist and inventor who promoted alternative crops to cotton and methods to prevent soil depletion. He is famous for developing hundreds of products using peanuts.
A Lakota war leader of the Oglala band in the 19th century. He took up arms against the U.S. federal government to fight against encroachment by white American settlers on Native American territory.

An English actor and director who, along with Ralph Richardson and John Gielgud, was one of a trio of male actors who dominated the British stage in the mid-20th century. He also starred in many classic films.
A British actress who won two Academy Awards for Best Actress, playing Scarlett O'Hara in 'Gone with the Wind' and Blanche DuBois in 'A Streetcar Named Desire.'
An American film actor often referred to as 'The King of Hollywood.' He is best known for his role as Rhett Butler in the 1939 epic 'Gone with the Wind.'
Also known as Siddhartha Gautama, he was a spiritual teacher who founded Buddhism. He taught that the path to enlightenment is found through the 'Middle Way' and the end of suffering.
The leader of Nazi Germany who initiated World War II in Europe and was central to the Holocaust. He is one of the most notorious figures in human history.
The Supreme Leader of North Korea since 2011. He is known for his country's isolation and his pursuit of nuclear weapons.
